characters: I WILL TAKE DAVE TO MY MOTHER'S.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: A DEAD CAT on the side of the road. Flies swarm around. C pass. Then, a thunderous rumble. The large tires of a PEN YELLOW SCHOOL BUS approach and come into focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus barrels down the two-lane blacktop, cutting throu the wooded countryside. JEFF DAHMER, 16, gazes out the window. His blank face is hidden behind WIRE-RIMMED GLASSES and SHAGGY, TOWHEADED H His eyes track the roadkill as the bus drives past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of jabbering TEENAGERS. Awkward freshman sit closer the front. Cooler kids own the back rows. In a middle row, Jeff is by his lonesome. Three average teenagers in the row directly in front of h play Twenty Questions:

dialogues.speaker: PIMPLE FACE
dialogues.text: Is it a person?

dialogues.speaker: BOWL CUT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRECKLE FACE
dialogues.text: Is the person living?

dialogues.speaker: BOWL CUT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PIMPLE FACE
dialogues.text: Is the person famous?

dialogues.speaker: BOWL CUT
dialogues.text: Sort of. The Bus driver grips the steering wheel as the bus hits a cluster of potholes. Everyone bounces, but no pause to th antics.  JOHN “DERF” BACKDERF, 17, sits in the front. He has a subversive confidence. Already resigned to his band-nerd status, he no longer gives a shit. He RIPS OUT a page fro his pad:

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dang it. The bumpy ride ruined his cartoon. He starts a new sketch that mocks the Bus Driver clenching the steering wheel:

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Calm down in the back. Sit down... The bus thunders along and turns onto WEST BATH ROAD. Jeff's eyes land on a NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER, late 40s, hand and lean, running in the same direction as the bus. He’s dressed in classic 70s running attire: Nikes, color strip tube socks, Adidas shorts. The bus stops. Several kids unload. The jogger runs ahead The bus picks up speed. Again, Jeff's eyes lock on the Neighborhood Jogger. Jeff studies the jogger’s stride, hi arms moving back & forth, thighs pumping, his stoic face. The bus accelerates. The Neighborhood Jogger starts to disappear behind the bus in the distance. Jeff heads up the aisle to the rear emergency exit door, trying to keep his sights on the jogger. He’s oddly fixat BUS DRIVER (CONT’D) Sit down in the back. Can’t see. Who is that? The front row freshmen shrug. They don’t know. BUS DRIVER (CONT’D) Hey! Other kids on the bus don’t know either. BUS DRIVER (CONT’D) Who's that? Derf looks up from his drawing pad.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: (eye rolls) That’s Jeff Dahmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff. Sit down. Jeff gets a tap on the shoulder. He turns around.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But I didn’t do anything. Jeff returns to his seat. The bus accelerates again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus dumps Jeff and some other kids off at their stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff steps up to the edge of the driveway and waits. Ther again, the Neighborhood Jogger approaches. Getting closer Jeff smiles, yet afraid to wave, as the jogger runs right past and continues up the slope. Once the jogger disappears over the hill, Jeff lowers his head and shuffles up the driveway. His shoulders thrust slightly forward. A strangely rigid and inflexible figure The stiff, awkward gait of a kid uncomfortable in the wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff dumps his backpack on the floor. He heads into the d The hallway walls are lined with dismal wood paneling. He hears chatter around the corner and curiously backtracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff enters the living room. A wall of windows looks out the wooded property sloping below. He discovers his fragile mother, JOYCE DAHMER, 41, on the sofa. She flips through a lookbook with MR. BURLMAN, a mi aged man with a slight twitch.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BURLMAN
dialogues.text: I-I-I think we cud frame the wall of windows with dwapes. Joyce looks up and notices--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Jeff. Hi. What about tennis practice?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Told you already, tennis season ended.  4. Mr. Burlman stands. His knees knock. He wobbles toward Je and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Burlman, my new interior decorator. Mr. Burlman’s twitching escalates.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BURLMAN
dialogues.text: Hehwo... braaa... Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Don’t be alarmed. Just a mild case of--

dialogues.speaker: MR. BURLMAN
dialogues.text: P-p-palsy.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: He’s a very talented designer.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BURLMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. D-d-dahmer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hi. Mr. Burlman trembles for a beat, stuck.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BURLMAN
dialogues.text: N-n-nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Jeff cuts through and exits the side door to return outsi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff chuckles to himself. The man’s tick amuses him, as i would any teenager.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (to himself) Dwapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff treads along the side of the road. Tennis sneakers g against the pebbly dirt. His pace slows. At his feet is the same roadkill, spotted from the bus. H TAPS THE DEAD CAT with his sneaker.  5. Jeff reaches down and picks it up. Holds it preciously in palms. He compulsively squeezes it. A slight sound escape from the decomposing insides. He smirks. Prepared for such a macabre discovery, Jeff pulls a crump plastic bag from his pocket and places the roadkill insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of teenagers on bikes maraud down the road. Littl concern for traffic.

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: c'mon. I don’t wanna miss Monty Python.

dialogues.speaker: LANKY
dialogues.text: Nudge nudge. Wink wink. Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: Say no more. Say no more.

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: Car. The teenagers swoop to the shoulder to let the car pass. keep peddling up the hill, huffing it. Suddenly, a DOG SNARLS at them from the edge of a propert and they peddle quicker, but the incline makes a quick getaway that much harder. SHORTY (CONT’D) We shoulda gone the other way. They run straight into Jeff who’s walking down the hill, carrying his souvenir.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You’re safe. The dog’s harmless and on a chain. The teens catch their breath. They’re immediately curious

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: Hey, Dahmer. Why are you carrying around... (glances in the bag) Ew!... Dead cat!?!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m gonna dissolve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: In some acid.

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: Whaaat? You’re so fulla crap.

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: Where did you get acid?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: My dad’s a chemist. I can get my hands on it easy.

dialogues.speaker: LANKY
dialogues.text: Yeah right--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Come see if you don’t believe me. They follow Jeff down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tucked in the woods on the side of the property, just fif feet from the road, is a MAN-MADE WOODEN SHED. Weeds grow the walls. Jeff and the gang of curious teenagers approac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. A rickety door. A musty space. Assortment of glass jars line the shelves. Each contains a brown, murky substance, individually labeled: Raccoon, Crow, Rabbit, e

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Welcome to my science project. Jeff places the dead cat on the table, then retrieves an ALUMINUM CONTAINER.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This acid is kinda weak... so it takes more than a couple of weeks for the flesh to dissolve. He pours acid into an empty jar, then forces the cat insi

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: Yuck. Jeff pours in some more acid and caps it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha-wha-why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I like to study bones. It-it interests me. What’s inside...

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: Aw, this is all total bullcrap! Dead animals, acid, c’mon. I bet these jars are fulla nothin’ but muddy water. Browbeaten beads of sweat dot Jeff's forehead. He pushes and reaches for a jar on a top shelf. Labeled: Raccoon.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: See this. I found it a month ago on Hametown Road. The flesh is almost completely dissolved now.

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: Ha! Yeah right. JEFF SNAPS. He THROWS THE JAR DOWN on the floor, shatteri on impact. Remnants of a half-dissolved raccoon spill out Flesh-pudding and bones. A jawbone. Gnarly raccoon feet. The STENCH is palpable, like a hundred rotten eggs. They gag, bumping into one another as they squeeze out the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and the other teenagers scatter away from the hut, holding their noses, retching. One vomits in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: BOSSY
dialogues.text: Gawd, Dahmer! You are such a freak. The teens run off, abandoning him. Jeff stands alone on t edge of his property - a stiff silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's father LIONEL DAHMER, 41, sits at the head of the dining table. A man of high intellect but unable to conne over quotidian details with his chafing wife or two sons, Jeff and DAVE, 10. Lionel serves himself some peas and carrots. Nearby, in t kitchen, Joyce anxiously pulls a chicken out of the oven.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (breaks the silence) Someone pass the iced tea. Dave reaches for it. Jeff takes the pitcher and passes i

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: How was your day, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Uneventful.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Demeson read more from Charlotte’s Web today--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dad, is there a stronger chemical I could use? Something that works faster?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Jeff, let your brother speak. What’s the book about, Dave?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It’s a... about a spider who talks to a pig named Wilbur who’s going to be slaughtered by a butcher.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Let me think. Joyce serves an under-cooked chicken.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Jeff, give your brother the drumsticks.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why? He doesn’t - I like the dark meat.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Jeff. Jeff obliges and gives the two drumsticks to his brother. They pick at the chicken. It’s raw on the bone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Dad, why is there toilet paper in our trees, again?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know, son. Jeff lowers his head. Lionel sneaks a peak in his directi  LIONEL (CONT’D) How's tennis, Jeff?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It ended over a week ago. But next year I got a chance to be ranked second singles.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Next fall, how about play some team sports? Or join some clubs... Jeff chokes on his food, and the intimidating suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Shoot, I forgot the potatoes. Joyce beelines back to the oven.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m in the Marching Band too.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I know, but... something new might lead to some better friends. Friends are our connection to the world. Joyce returns with hot potatoes and drops them on the pla

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Chicken’s red inside, Mom. Joyce stops moving and examines the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You don’t like my cooking? New house rule. We eat our mistakes. Joyce sits. The two boys pick at the food. Lionel and Joy make eye contact across the table. Jeff notes their glare full of resentment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drove of students mill about. It’s a quintessential pub high school - soulless, modular formation of red brick. A school bus pulls in and drops off another herd of teenage Some kids gather around the SCHOOL ROCK. This defaced bou is the students’ billboard: graffiti, couples’ initials, the declarations “Balderelli Sucks” and “Class of ‘77 Rul  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff walks warily down the overcrowded hall, teeming with 70s trends, hormones, and bravado. Platform shoes. Bell bottoms. Layered long hair and sideburns. “Sabbath Bloody Sabbath” by Black Sabbath blares from a beatbox. Two senior BULLY-JOCKS shove Jeff into the wall--

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCKS
dialogues.text: Outta my way, Dumber! Dumb ass. Jeff slides to the floor. He scurries to pick up his book

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working by himself, Jeff peers into a microscope. Several rows ahead, Derf and two rascally cohorts, KENT a MIKE, joke around. Kent wears a KISS T-shirt, almost alwa He also wears a skeptical attitude. Mike is constantly jovial, with a paunchy, short physique to match. MS. BOWLES, 50s, limps around class. Her metal ankle-brac creaks and distracts, as does her lisp.

dialogues.speaker: MS. BOWLES
dialogues.text: Mr. John Backderf. Have you matched, um, the chloroplatz?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: We’re workin’ on it, Miss Bowles.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re on question sixteen to be precise. Ms. Bowles looks at their papers. Derf’s margins are fill with doodles of the girls’ butts in the row ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MS. BOWLES
dialogues.text: Gather your stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Me? We’re-we’re taking turns on the scope, Miss--

dialogues.speaker: MS. BOWLES
dialogues.text: Over here. With Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Geez. Ms. Bowles leads Derf to the back row.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MS. BOWLES
dialogues.text: Jeff, keep on the same slide and give Mr. Backderf a look. Derf focuses to complete the assignment. MS. BOWLES strol down the side of her classroom and glances in a cabinet. LOCKS EYES on a jarred FETAL PIG on a shelf, unaware Derf now copying his answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff carries his tray from the kitchen into a boisterous cafeteria. He sulks past the stereotypical clusters of cliques at separate tables: PSYCHO-STONERS, led by LLOYD FIGG, giving each other dead arms. Lloyd’s the school’s premier delinquent. BULLY-JOCKS, led by the Quarterback, flirting with the PR QUEEN WANNABES at the next table. BAND NERDS, led by Derf, who chortle over a Mad Magazine trade music cassettes. Jeff finds a seat at a table against the back wall. The t is empty, except for OLIVER ZLATKA, 16, a sophomore and t school’s effeminate weakling. Jeff sits at the far end to lessen their association.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Hey. Jeff nods, keeping to himself. He shyly eats. OLIVER (CONT’D) I’m going away this summer to a wilderness camp. But in exchange my dad said I can get tickets to see Neil Sedaka in concert.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: My favorite.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I know. Wanna go?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Um, sure. Prom Queen Wannabe WENDY WATKINS butts in--

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (nudges Jeff) Hey, kid, you’re in my spot. Move.  12. Jeff slides closer to Oliver. Wendy stands on an empty ch and gets the crowd’s attention-- WENDY (CONT’D) Over here. Everyone!

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PROM QUEEN WANNABE
dialogues.text: Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Quiet. Thanks. I’m only talking to the seniors, so the rest of you just keep your traps shut. As you know, I’m on the Prom Planning Committee and I've - we've put our hearts into the event which is right around the corner. It’s going to be the best prom ever and just a reminder that voting for prom King and Queen ends this Friday. And, and it just came to my-- Figg knocks over Oliver's food tray.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Hey, Faggot. She’s talking. Laughter erupts.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Stop that--

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: You’re a little fruit.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Freakin’ juniors, stop that. Figg starts to give Oliver a wedgie in the aisle. Bully-J cheer him on. More widespread laughter and applause, even from Derf and his band-nerd cohorts. LUNCHROOM MONITORS swarm in and pull Figg away. In the confusion, Jeff slips out, undetected. He’s relieved he wasn’t the target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his work table, Jeff pulls a lumpy mass - wrapped in a undershirt - from his backpack. He unveils the fetal pig, stolen from Biology class. Jeff holds it preciously in hi palms and thumbs its belly.  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff stares blankly at The Mary Tyler Moore Show as he finishes a bowl of cereal, blocking out his parents’ argu in the living room nearby--

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you did that without discussing it first.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why? You always say no to everything.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Joyce, I’m not paying for a crony drape hanger.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Interior decorator. There’s a difference. Dave sidles down the hall to get a look.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You're not capable of this kind of project. It needs attention, dedication. Next week you’re going to want to do pottery.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: That’s hardly - I’m ready to go back to work.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What - how?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (gesturing to her son) David will be eleven. Lionel shoos David away.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s old enough to let himself in. Lynn Watkins up the street went back to work. Cynthia Bakula is selling real estate now, she’s not even around on the weekends. Even Jane Kyriazis is doing bookkeeping.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: May I remind you, you’ve been back from the mental hospital for less than a year. Besides.  14. A strained pause. LIONEL (CONT’D) (walks away) Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Forget what?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: ... Just a month ago you saw a UFO fly past the house, and you chased it down the street in your bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Jerk. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE’S BEDROOM - LATER Jeff and Dave lie in twin beds, forced to listen to their parents’ continued argument on the other side of the wall

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: GODDAMMIT, JOYCE, I’M NOT GOING TO have this argument again! It’s not even about that guy. Dave sniffles. Jeff wipes a tearful eye.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're a fascist, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're talking about nothing. We have nothing left to say to each other--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have plenty, don’t get me started.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shut the hell up.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’ve had it with-- SLAM! A door shuts in a face. Absolute silence, except fo Dave's sniffling. Jeff slides over to his brother’s bed t comfort him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Are they going to hit each other?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No, they just yell.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. HICKS, the heavy-set armpit-stained band leader, cond a rehearsal. Jeff plays trumpet. In the back row, Derf pl tuba beside Kent on percussion. Mr. Hicks wraps up the so

dialogues.speaker: MR. HICKS
dialogues.text: That sounds excellent. The trumpet and clarinets were pitch perfect. A momentary proud smile crosses Jeff's face.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HICKS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Groovy. You play like that at our year end recital and we’re gonna blow scalps off the audience... Band members sort of understand his latest idiom. MR. HICKS (CONT’D) «+. Once again, from the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver lurks among the parked cars, hiding. Two BULLY-JOC find him and approach. Oliver backs up, timid.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: Hey, faggot. There you are.

dialogues.speaker: GOOCH
dialogues.text: You've been avoiding us all day. Jeff appears - his backpack and trumpet case slung over h shoulder - not expecting to find anyone other than Oliver

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Hey, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: GOOCH
dialogues.text: Coming to save the day, Dahmer?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No, no--

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: Are you going to defend this homo with your trumpet case?

dialogues.speaker: GOOCH
dialogues.text: I got a trumpet you can blow.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I was just gonna tell him somethin’.  16.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: Go ahead, I’d like to see this.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: (blurts out) Jeff, I got the Neil Sedaka tickets for this Saturday. Jeff acts surprised, like he doesn’t know Oliver’s refere The bullies encroach on Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: You guys going together? Cute.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m not going to any concert - it’s not my thing, you know.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: But my dad said he’1l pick you up this Saturday around five... The Bully-Jocks beat up on Oliver - it’s routine. Jeff sl away, abandoning the scene for his own safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel pulls into the driveway in his gray 1974 AMC Pacer grabs his leather briefcase and heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel looks for Jeff around the house. He finds Dave in den watching Family Feud on TV.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Hi, Dave. So where’s your brother?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I think he’s in his lab. Been there for hours.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: And your mother? Dave shrugs.  17.

dialogues.speaker: E/I. HUT
dialogues.text: LIONEL SWINGS OPEN THE DOOR AND BARGES IN. Jeff is busy examining rodent bones. The fetal pig is in a jar labeled Baby Pig.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dad, you’re never home this early. Realizing the breadth of the dead animal collection, Lion SNATCHES several jars for a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad!?!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That’s enough, Jeff. Lionel leaves with the jars. Jeff's confused, but his attention quickly returns to the bone fragments. Suddenly, Lionel impetuously PULLS THE DOOR OFF THE HINGE

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dad! ?!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You're spending too much time in here. With a burst of adrenaline, Lionel stiff-arms Jeff to kee away and starts pulling more jars from the hut.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Don’t, don’t... A moment later; Lionel dumps the jars in the trash can. Jeff impotently circles the hut as Lionel continues to em it of its jars, acid, and other contents. Jeff moves to s some and prevent his father--

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (assertive) I let you have a pet cemetery when you were a kid, but then this... Dave has wandered over and watches from a distance. LIONEL (CONT’D) You need, Jeff, to come out, to come out of your shell, something more normal.  18.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m in the band. I’m--

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You're not hearing me. Lionel drags out the work table. LIONEL (CONT’D) I don’t understand what happened... He pushes and sways the hut, loosening its construction. tears it apart until it COLLAPSES, revealing Jeff shudder with fear. Jeff's most contained obsession is now history Lionel catches his breath. Jeff and Dave stand around and look at the flattened hut as Lionel drags the trashcan aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff hides the contents of one jar (which he clearly swip behind a tree. He covers the bones with leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel, Jeff, and Dave pick at leftovers for dinner. Dave hums as he eats, while Jeff pouts. Joyce is absent.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You always liked performing as a kid. Jeff, maybe... how about doing theater? Or something else? Any of it could... At least help your acceptance to college. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff keeps to himself, head lowered, in the back of class

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff eats by himself. SCHOOL SPIRIT approaches, gregariou

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL SPIRIT
dialogues.text: Wanna sign up for Key Club? (no response) We're looking for new recruits who can be active over the summer. Just because school’s out, it doesn’t mean we stop helping people in our community. Would you like to help others in your community?  19.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf, Kent, and Mike are joined by buddy NEIL, also a jokester but the most empathetic of the bunch. They take turns tossing a broken bike pedal into a garbage pail, li game of horse, wasting time...

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: We're still trapped in this wasteland for another year. Jeff creeps past.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I know - it might drive me crazy. Senior year’s going to suck, I’m ready to get out. Jeff starts to approach, hoping to join in their game. A tense TEACHER pops out of the side door--

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Hey, are you in an after-school program?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not right now--

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Tennis season is over.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Marching band is only in the fall--

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Well then, get off school grounds. The day’s over. You can’t be hanging around with nothing to do. Go, get... Derf, Kent, Mike and Neil withdraw, tittering. None of th notice Jeff nearby. He cuts the other way. Figg body checks Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Wanna catch a buzz? Cupped in Figg’s hand is a joint.  20.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Straight off the boat. Seven bucks. (no response) Yesterday, I freakin toked-up and hit a thousand in mailbox baseball. Hesitantly considering it, Jeff checks his pockets. They’ empty except for a PLASTIC BAG.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why the bag, dude?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I pick up roadkill, but I’m trying to quit.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: I’1l get you roadkill. Stick with me. Figg drifts by, already onto his next potential customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sits beside the flattened hut. He FONDLES the small, recovered collection of rodent-size bones. Then, the Neighborhood Jogger runs up the street, approaching. Jeff checks his watch as he edges closer to street. He lurks in the bushes, waiting. The Neighborhood Jogger trots past Jeff's house. Jeff's breathing quickens, excited. Trailing the jogger, Jeff weaves through the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff JUMPS OUT onto the shoulder of the road. He scurries hesitantly, up the incline CHASING AFTER THE JOGGER. Further up the slope, the jogger passes Wendy Watkins (th prom queen wannabe). She’s retrieving mail. Her IRISH SET yaps at the jogger’s heels. She pulls at the leash.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, so sorry. Jeff slows, keeping a distance. He watches the jogger run away. Checks his watch once again.  21. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - EVENIN Jeff stares out the window, eyes locked on a squirrel sta right back at him, frozen on a branch. Lionel drops by.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Stu-studying for finals.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Can I have a minute? Look, I went through it too. It’s completely normal. Puberty is this period when your sex glands become functional and your hypothalamus signals hormonal changes that stimulate the pituitary. Then, the gonads and testis... anyway, it’s an awkward time. You mustn’t forget all boys go through it too, not just you, so there’s no reason to be shy.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That’s not it, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Try me. I spoke to someone at work about - I’m ready to listen.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Most everyone's known me since elementary school, they’re not going to change their minds now. It’1l be easier after I graduate.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: But you can’t - look... okay... the hut... You have to understand, Jeff, I just get mad at you sometimes because I see in you things I don’t like about myself. I spend too much time in the chemistry lab, I know. I just want you to be more active than I was, have friends in a way I never really... so... I have something. Lionel steps away. He returns and presents TWO DUMBBELLS. LIONEL (CONT’D) I picked these up at The Summit Mall. It'll help, I think. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll be more impressive, you might find it rewarding. And maybe some girl might notice you. Right? Okay? Jeff stares back, blankly. Lionel sets the dumbbells down withdraws. Jeff pushes them away with his heel. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE’S BEDROOM - THAT NI Jeff hears his parents bickering again.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have to start somewhere--

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It makes no sense. It’s ugly. How much?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just a hundred and twenty-five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: For a pink fucking foot stool? That’s ludicrous, Joyce! DESPERATE KNOCKS at the door. Jeff has placed the dumbbel as doorstops. He moves them away and lets in Dave. Jeff p out:

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I think we should divorce.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Divorce!?! Over this foot stool?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: YOU DON’T BELIEVE ME? Jeff barges out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff SNAPS, vehemently knocking over a lamp.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Will you stop! Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Stop. Fighting. Seriously.  23.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Dammit. This doesn’t concern you.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Go to your room, Jeff. Jeff stews, staring at them. Odd panting. The room is tig with tension. Then, Jeff obediently retreats. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - CONTIN Jeff locks the door. Eyes well up with tears. A jumble of emotions. He returns one dumbbell to the door and takes t other one to his bed. Dave watches as Jeff starts doing b curls, furiously.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: BATH, OHIO during a carefree July day. TEENAGERS roam on bicycles. CHILDREN play in a park. KIDS jump into the town pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff rallies with Neil. Jeff hits a winning forehand.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Wow, nice slice. Why didn’t you hit like that last season? Jeff shrugs, not comfortable with compliments, as he fetc balls. Neil fetches his water.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m heading over to the pool to cool off. Wanna come? Jeff considers it, then shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff treads water in the deep end. Fixated on a group of young boys frolicking nearby. He goggles at their lean, weightless bodies glistening in the water.  24.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Jeff, Jeff, move over. I’m gonna dive right on you. Jeff swims away. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - DAY Jeff sits at the edge of his bed doing more bicep curls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sets a small, makeshift trap. He eyes a squirrel nea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several seniors paint “Class of ‘78 Rules” on the school rock. In the b.g., Jeff walks through the front entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff trudges down the hall. He’s taller and more muscular after a growth spurt and summer spent lifting weights. He fits into his father’s hand-me-down dress shirt and slack and carries his old, leather briefcase. In contrast to th colorful 70s fashion in full bloom, this, ironically, cas studious appearance to teachers scanning the halls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. FEDELE, a jovial scatterbrain, struggles to get comma of his classroom.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: Everyone, quiet down. I know it’s exciting to catch up after summer break. Jeff is detached in the back row. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) I have rules, I must go over, I have rules. Your attention, students. But no one in class really cares. Fedele’s weak reputatio precedes him. Students pass notes and gossip. Derf doodle cartoon of Fedele for an audience of onlookers. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) That’s enough. Quiet. Alright, good. Thank you. Mr. Fedele starts passing out textbooks from the stack.  25. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) Your senior year American History Honors class will focus on Federal Government and our Presidents. Why is history important? Mr. Fedele notices Jeff hunkered down in the back. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) You. Why is history important? Jeff mumbles. MR. FEDELE (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Uh, it’s important... dunno.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: You all must speak clearly.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (mumbling, like a moan) I dunno. Chortles from students. Derf turns. Jeff mumbles again - time intentionally for attention. Laughter escalates. The reaction surprises Jeff. He smirks, then:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: BRRRRRAAAA dunno. Laughter ERUPTS.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: Quiet! Let me answer. We can only really know about ourselves if we come to better understand our past. Turn to page ten in your new text books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIIING. The period bell halts Fedele’s lecture. Kids head the door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: Wait, before you forget, take a permission slip and packets home for our spring trip to DC. Everyone must get a parent to sign it.  26. A fellow student approvingly pats Jeff on the shoulder as they head out. Jeff grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DRAMA GEEK finishes her audition song:

dialogues.speaker: DRAMA GEEK
dialogues.text: If happy little bluebirds fly beyond the rainbow, Why, oh why can’t I?

dialogues.speaker: MUSICAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Thank you, very nice, Melody, beautiful as always. (scanning the audition sign- up sheet) Next up, Oliver Zlatka. Oliver scampers onto the stage. Jeff is in the audience, slouched in a seat against the w

dialogues.speaker: MUSICAL DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi, Oliver. Apologies. Unfortunately, I was instructed by the PTA to do a musical this year, to be more inclusive.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: (sings off key) Somewhere over the rainbow, way up high, There’s a land that I’ve heard of, once in a lullaby. Jeff wipes nervous beads of sweat from his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Somewhere over the rainbow, skies are blue, And the dreams... Oliver stops himself, knowing his audition is awful. An awkward silence. Oliver exits the auditorium, head down.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Next up. Jeff Dahmer. Musical Director waits. No one comes on stage.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICAL DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jeff Dahmer? Those scattered around the seats look around. Jeff covers face. A look of self-doubt comes over him. He slips out.  27. MUSICAL DIRECTOR (CONT’D) Okay, lost your chance. Next up is Alan Tomczak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sits at a reading table scanning the quiet scene. He studies a pack of STUDENTS doing homework at another tabl light bulb goes off... Jeff GROWLS. LOUDER AND LOUDER, evolving into a widesprea moan. Shoulders jerk up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: ... Baaaaaaa! Arrrr! Baaaaa! Totally unexpected, the other students laugh. MRS. WOODARD, the irascible librarian, STORMS IN from a b aisle. Finds everyone reading, swallowing their amusement

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOODARD
dialogues.text: Who did that!? She beelines it over to the table of snickering students. MRS. WOODARD (CONT’D) Was it you? Behave yourself or get out of my library. They remain tight-lipped. Mrs. Woodard looks around, then returns to her chores filing away books. Again, it goes quiet... then:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (moaning) Brrra! Thmaaa! More snickers. Mrs. Woodard bursts in, again. She’s FUMIN Still no clue--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WOODARD
dialogues.text: Who keeps making that noise? Jeff lowers his head. A smirk creeps across his face. Fee a connection to the other kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff passes Neil and his friends, including Derf, and hin

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hey man, watch this.  28. Jeff steps into the middle of the main hallway and throws sudden, sprawling

dialogues.speaker: EPILEPTIC-LIKE FIT
dialogues.text: His arms FLAIL. His tongue wags out of his mouth. It’s hilarious and bizarre. A crowd gathers. Laughter and cheers. Derf, Neil, Mike, and Kent rush over for a front row view Widespread laughter from the swelling crowd. Though, a fe straight-laced kids flee in confusion. Jeff continues spazzing, center stage. RIIING. Students scurry off to class. Yet, Jeff continues flailing for a few stragglers. Appreciating the display, is one of the very last to split. Becomes an empty hallway. Only then, Jeff gets up and hea to class himself, pleased with the result.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classrooms empty out at the end of another period. Derf, Neil, Kent, and Mike gather at their lockers.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dude, what’s the dealio with Dahmer?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Is he insane or what?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I think he’s hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s new.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Heard he spazzed in Math too.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: For the last couple of days, he’s been doing a Dahmer, I call it.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I’ve never really spoken to him.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: We rally in tennis but that’s it.  29. Kent nudges Derf. There’s Jeff shuffling past. They give a thumbs up. Jeff BLEEPS back--

dialogues.speaker: BAAAAAA.
dialogues.text: They’re amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gym class. Two Team Captains pick players for dodgeball.

dialogues.speaker: TEAM CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: And I’1l take Backderf. A couple more names are called. Jeff and a scrawny kid ar the last ones left. Scrawny is picked. TEAM CAPTAIN (CONT’D) Uh, alright... I guess we got Doofus Dahmer. The teams take their sides, readying for play. COACH NATA whistles. A mad rush to the balls. A BLITZKRIEG OF BALLS FLY in Jeff's direction, along with insults. He’s quickly obliterated. He crosses to the sideline. More balls strike him in the head.

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: (tardy) No headhunting. Moments later; as the game continues, Derf is also out. Together on the sidelines:

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Doesn't it bother you? The way some of them talk about you, right to your face?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Used to it. Somehow I’1l get ‘em back.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Won’t get any better for these psycho- stoner losers. At least our best days are ahead of us. Jeff nods, though uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sits alone. Derf drops by.  30.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Hey, Dahmer. Curious if you want to join us at our table. Jeff turns. He sees Neil and other band nerd buddies watching, waiting for Jeff's response.

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No reason a champion spazzer has to sit here in hell. C’mon over. We got parking lot views. Jeff takes his tray and follows Derf to his table. Neil p out a seat for Jeff. They welcome him with Dahmerisms - BAAAA, THMAAAA, etc.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Kudos on your freakin’ spazzes, dude. Totally classic.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: We dig it.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Where'd you get the idea?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: C'mon, man.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Dude, like, you know what it reminds me of. There’s this decorator in town that my parents hired. He used to have little fits in our living room, til my toads fired him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Burlman. Yeah, my mom hired him too.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Knew it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: After five months, all he added is an ugly pink foot stool. They laugh.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (spazzes) And lacey dwapes. They laugh harder.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Where have you been? I say we form The Dahmer Fan Club.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jeff brightens.

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s just so much time left. And with Dahmer as our fearless leader, I really think we can disrupt Revere High and ensure we go out in style.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: In infamy.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, and if we don’t, I’m gonna do something crazy like kill the Pope. Jeff smiles, likely for the first time in school in ages.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I already... (flips through his notebook ) Drew you. Derf shows his cartoonish drawing “Dahmer as a Telephone Pole” of Jeff stiff & upright. Compliments for the humoro depiction. Jeff relishes the attention.

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And as part of the Dahmer Fan Club, I appoint myself The Minister of Propaganda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf hurries to color in some last minute touches on a ha drawn poster. A subversive chuckle to himself. Bandmates retrieve him and pull at him.  32.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Derf, we’re late. C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pep rally. Cheerleaders prance around in unison. The foot team files onto the court in their new jerseys. The Marching Band is stacked into the bleachers, beside t rest of the student body. They play the quintessential pe rally song. Derf plays tuba. Kent on bass drum. Hoisted o the wall above them is Derf’s poster. It’s a large cartoo an angry running back stomping Jeff Dahmer flat on his ba It reads: GO MINUTEMEN! CRUSH THE COMETS! (A speech bubbl reads: BAAAAA!) Several rows ahead, Jeff plays trumpet. Once the song end Jeff glances back at his large cartoon. Gives a thumbs up Derf. Center court, the officious VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI tak the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: Thank you, Revere High Marching Band! Be proud Minutemen! Cheers & applause from the bleachers. A couple of psycho- stoners taunt Oliver, wearing sneakers decorated with sch colors.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHO-STONER
dialogues.text: Hey, gay boy, aren’t you supposed to be up there with the cheerleaders? Psycho-stoner shoves Oliver off his seat. Oliver fumbles before finding another seat two rows back, fleeing confli

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: (takes the mic.) Hello, Minutemen! Are you ready for a winning season? Some of these guys have been playing ball together since grade school, and they’ve been preparing for this season their whole lives. Let’s hear it for Team Captain Hirsch. The Cheerleaders lead a cheer as the Team Captain takes center court, but instead The Dahmer Fan Club hails:

dialogues.speaker: THE DAHMER FAN CLUB
dialogues.text: Go Dahmer! Dahmer Rules!  33. Kent pounds on his drum. Derf blows his tuba, off tune. F the stands, other periphery members disrupt. Among them:

dialogues.speaker: BRAAAAAAA. MRAAAAA. THMAAAAAA.
dialogues.text: Just as Team Captain/Quarterback Hirsch is about to speak

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Go Dahmer! Jeff hoists the bell of his trumpet upward and BLOWS A LO SCREECHING CRY that drowns out the Team Captain’s opening remarks. Laughter erupts.

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: Cut that out, kid. Musical Director is frozen in shock. A hush runs through crowd. Jeff daringly BLOWS ANOTHER UNRULY SCREECH, rousin more band members to copy and make noise. Balderelli jumps into action and climbs into the stands.

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: What’s your name? Balderelli GRABS Jeff by the arm and drags him off the li The Dahmer Fan Club and others applaud the disturbance. Balderelli leads Jeff to the door--

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: What’s your name? Before Jeff can stutter out an answer-- VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI (CONT’D) I have bigger fish to fry. You hear me kid?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I didn’t, I didn’t... Vice Principal Balderelli returns inside, pulling the doo closed behind him. The door locks, leaving Jeff outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff waits in the bushes. Eagerness in his eyes. Palpitat with anticipation. He hears him coming - HUFF! HUFF! - up hill.  34. The Neighborhood Jogger trots by, muscles pulsing, chest hair bouncing above his headband. Jeff stares, mouth agape. TITILLATED... Then, just as quickly, the jogger breezes by up the hill Jeff deflates... his mood shifts to shame and confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dahmer Fan Club pal around near their lockers. A grou HOT GIRLS mingle nearby.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: They’re totally out of our league.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I know, a primo target. Someone do a Dahmer, do a Dahmer. Jeff is more than willing to impress. He hands over his textbooks and runs up the hallway, FLAILING his arms.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hurricane drill. HURRICANE DRILL. He spooks the girls, but runs right past them. His spazz culminates outside the TEACHER’S LOUNGE.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help, help! Yet, the teachers are disinterested, mere head shakes.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: So wrong, it’s so wrong... Jeff continues to spazz, gaining no further attention fro the adults, as he continues flailing out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Where’s he going!? In hysterics, The Dahmer Fan Club high five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hungover ENGLISH TEACHER rests his head on his desk. blackboard reads: Today’s Assign., Read Machiavelli’s The Prince, Chap 1 & 2. QUIETLY. THANK YOU! Derf draws a cartoon - “Dahmer in a Bag of Groceries.” PE plainly cute & keenly observant, looks on.  35.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Is Dahmer your muse?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Sure looks like it. You’re talented.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you sketch me? Derf blushes.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (nearby, interjecting) I can draw you.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Let's see.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Okay... first, get out of your chair. And lay down on the floor. Chuckles. Penny actually follows his direction and sits o the floor. Jeff retrieves chalk from the side blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lay down. And act dead. Penny lies back, into a corpse position.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What are you, a necrophiliac? More chuckles. The teacher adjusts his napping position--

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH TEACHER
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Keep reading. Jeff traces Penny’s body in chalk. Everyone gathers aroun

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: There. Ta-da. Laughter erupts. The hungover English Teacher snaps up.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH TEACHER
dialogues.text: Quiet. What did I say!?! Quiet. Everyone snickers and returns to his/her seat. Jeff grins relishing in his role.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Returning home, Jeff has a jump in his step. He passes hi brother practicing wheelies on his banana seat bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, Jeff, wanna play?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Can’t, got some friends coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff breezes through the kitchen, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dad, Mom? I have good news. He hears some RETCH-LIKE SOUNDS, squashing his enthusiasm

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM AREA
dialogues.text: Joyce leans against the wall, quivering. Unaware Jeff is watching, she takes a cocktail of pills and swallows them with a pinch of water, growling.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom... Mom... She turns to him, trembling. She BLEEPS, reminiscent of h school time spazzes--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Jjjeffft.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: M-mom, I thought you stopped. Wh-why don’t you--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Shhh-shhh-uuuuu--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Go back - go back to the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I’d ruther shooot myself than go back there. Arrrrr - don’t need...  37. Joyce drops down onto the sofa, still twitching.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I thought you weren’t--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Doctors don’t know what I need. Shhh, I've been taking these since I was pregnant with you, just shhh, leave me alone. She rests her face in a pillow, sweating. She sighs, wait for the side effects to lessen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf and Neil arrive in Derf’s rusted Chevy Vegas. They i during the last measures of Devo’s “Mongoloid,” then get and head to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: How can you like that punk crap?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Devo’s from right down the street. At least I don’t listen to that Kiss crap like Kent. So Junior High. They knock, then realize it’s unlocked. They head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff rushes toward Derf and Neil and ushers them back out

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hey. Why don’t we hang outside?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Thought we were hanging in your den? I brought some bootlegs.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, uh, my Mom’s resting.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And, kind of embarrassed by the pink foot stool and lace drapes. They chuckle.  38.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Are you in the new club?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That’s my brother. Get lost.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My dad keeps telling Jeff he should join some new clubs.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Beat it, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Hey, doesn’t Wendy Watkins live just down the street? Heard she still lives at home, even though she graduated.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Are you friends?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know I exist.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff, Derf, and Neil edge closer to the house.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Which is her bedroom window?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Watch this, chumps. Neil heads to the front door and rings the bell. He puts serious face. Derf and Jeff hide behind a bush to watch f afar. Wendy answers the door. Her Irish Setter at her sid

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m here for the interview.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Huh? They said you agreed to be interviewed. I write for the Revere High newspaper.  39.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: The Lantern?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yep, doing a story on past homecoming queens.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Guess I could spare ten minutes. Derf and Jeff pop out of the bushes to join. WENDY (CONT’D) Wait a sec. This some kind of joke? Neil breaks his poker face. Wendy shoos him away. Neil, D and Jeff scatter, laughing. EXT. REVERE HIGH SCHOOL - FRONT YARD —- DAY Derf, Mike, and Kent jokingly push Jeff toward a group of students gathering around the painted school rock.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Stop it. I’m not, no way, no.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: C’mon, make your dad proud. SWISH PAN to THE ROCK CLIMBING CLUB posing for their Year Photo. Neil adjusts the camera on the tripod.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: So this is everyone for the Rock Climbing Club’s Yearbook photo?

dialogues.speaker: ROCK CLIMBING CLUB MEMBER
dialogues.text: Yep. Neil focuses the camera. Now in the b.g., Jeff continues resist The Dahmer Fan Club’s shoves. Neil snaps the photo capturing The DFC’s antics in the frame.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Excellent!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUES
dialogues.text: The Dahmer Fan Club prods Jeff into the Student Council Yearbook photo. Jeff is less resistant. Neil snaps a phot

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Hey, Jeff.  40.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (self-consciously) Hey, Oliver. THE DAHMER FAN CLUB slip Jeff into The Lantern photo. JEFF STEPS INTO the KEY CLUB photo. Neil snaps the pictur JEFF STANDS in the DISCO CLUB photo. He’s the only one no imitating Travolta’s iconic pose. Jeff blankly stares at the camera in THE DEBATE TEAM phot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff slips into the back row of the NATIONAL HONOR SOCIET photo. Near him stand Derf, Kent, and Mike. Other club members notice Jeff in line.

dialogues.speaker: NATIONAL HONOR STUDENT
dialogues.text: He’s not in National Honor Society.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Shut your piehole. In the aisle, Neil lines up the framing and directs a Tea on how to snap the photo, then runs ahead to step into pl

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: On the count of three, smile everyone. One. Two. Three. Everyone smiles, except Jeff who blankly stares ahead. CL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Neil enter. They find Lionel at the dining table focused on work papers.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dad, you'd be proud. I’m in a bunch of new clubs. Great for my college application.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That's great, son. Which ones?-- Joyce races by and lifts Lionel’s briefcase off the table

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t go here.  41.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: JESUS CHRIST, JOYCE, I’m working, give that back. Joyce. DAMMIT, JOYCE! Jeff is embarrassed by his parents’ outburst. Sensing the tension, Neil cordially retreats.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Uh. Jeff, actually, I gotta get home for dinner. See you in school. Don’t let the fame go to your head. Jeff lowers his head as Neil leaves. INT. KENT’S FAMILY HOME - FURNISHED BASEMENT - NIGHT The Dahmer Fan Club hang out. Jeff is fascinated - if not obsessed - with a mounted deer head.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Awesome. What do you think they do with the insides?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I dunno, weirdo. You mean venison? While others flip through a titty mag.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Like these girls are as old as my mom.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I swiped my dad’s collection, what can I say?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dude, just drop by my work and pick out some fresh ones. Shhh. I’m dialing... Derf dials a number from the yellow pages.

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s ringing. (into phone) Hehwo? Burlman Intewiors. Do you sell swipcovers? MR. BURLMAN’S VOICE Why, yes we doooo!

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: And dwapery? Do you sell dwapes?  42. MR. BURLMAN’S VOICE Yes, we have m-m-many colors and fabrics--

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: How about animal skins? Zeebwa and tiger skins-- MR. BURLMAN’S VOICE Hey! You’ve called here befooore. Mr. Burlman hangs up. Derf and his buddies crack up. Thou Jeff's laugh is a discordant, out-of-step cackle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf bags groceries on the register line. Dropping by, Je and Mike wave in his direction and head straight for the

dialogues.speaker: MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: Mike scans titty mags on display, and pulls out an Easyri Magazine. He slips it into a Mad Magazine. Derf joins.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Good timing, my shift just ended. Inside, glossy photos of topless women straddling motorcycles. They bury their heads, googly eyed. Jeff dri away, concealing his disinterest. A MOTHER WITH SHOPPING CART passes, forcing Derf and Mike hide the magazines for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you gonna, buy it tucked in like that, but don’t get caught. From the next aisle, Jeff POPS his head over the shelf--

dialogues.speaker: BAAAAAAAA.
dialogues.text: Startling them. They hear more spastic GRUNTS and BLEEPS, fading into the distance. They scurry to get a better loo

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCE SECTION
dialogues.text: Jeff throws a spontaneous EPILEPTIC-LIKE SPAZZ, for its o sake, spooking a MOTHER & CHILD. Jeff KNOCKS OVER a pyramid presentation of fresh apples. and Mike, as witness, snort and fall over laughing.  43. This encourages Jeff to go further. He swipes a stack of oranges. Tears apart a cabbage. He FLAILS and GRUNTS on the floor. Shoppers watch in dism STORE MANAGER bolts over.

dialogues.speaker: STORE MANAGER
dialogues.text: What’s going on!? What’s going on?! Undeterred, Jeff continues WRITHING HIS BODY. STORE MANAGER (CONT’D) Stop this. Get up! Store Manager grabs Jeff's shirt but gets entangled in hi spazz and tumbles over, falling on Jeff. They TUSSLE. Sto Manager wrestles his way free, then hoists Jeff to his fe STORE MANAGER (CONT’D) You have any respect for property? Any sense of decency, young man?! Jeff evades the Store Manager’s scowl. STORE MANAGER (CONT’D) You hear me? What’s your name? Jeff grunts an indiscernible reply. STORE MANAGER (CONT’D) What’s your name? Huh? Jeff bleeps another reply. STORE MANAGER (CONT’D) Who put you up to this? Store Manager notices Derf and Mike tucked behind the fre corn and cabbage, muffling their laughter. He darts right Derf. Jeff dusts himself off and bows. STORE MANAGER (CONT’D) Mr. Backderf. Is this your doing? Jeff and Mike flee the scene, stolen titty magazines in h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Mike head toward Derf’s Chevy Vegas to wait it o Derf emerges from the store, bundling up his work apron.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Oh shit. Did you get fired?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Almost. Begged him I had nothing to do with it, need that money for college. That’s it. Jeff, we can’t do that stuff in public, gonna get squashed by the damn adults. It’s different - teachers are zombies.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yep, alright.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: School’s safe.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey dude, that’s Doctor York. Doctor York! DOCTOR YORK steps out of his shiny foreign car. Doctor Yo is the Neighborhood Jogger. Jeff turns demure, stiffens u

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Doctor York. What’s shakin’?

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Hi Michael. How are your parents?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Deathly ill.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: What? My gosh, how come?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Just jiving ya. They’re good.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: And that cough of yours?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Went away, pretty quickly actually.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Great, be good. Stay out of trouble. Dr. York/Neighborhood Jogger heads toward the grocery sto

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He runs past my house every Monday, Wednesday, Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Um, okay. He holds my balls when I cough. Beat that, faggot.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Sounds like you dig it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Spazz. Derf nudges Jeff, and they amble off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel pulls in. A brown Oldsmobile Omega is already park in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel places down his briefcase on the kitchen counter a heads into the den where Jeff and Dave watch CHiPS.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Who’s over? One of your friends, Jeff?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (barges in, stands proud) I bought it.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Only two thousand miles. Joyce steps away, drawing Lionel into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (follows after her) With what?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I’m financing it, not to worry.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I laid down a deposit, how else? Jeff shields Dave as they eavesdrop from around the corne

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Without discussing it? Give me back my checkbook, that was for groceries and--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: My name’s on it.  46.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You're returning it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Over my dead body. It’s final sale. Lionel stews. Then digs deep into a cabinet and pulls out dusty bottle of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I need a drink. Lionel washes down his anger with a swig and steps outsid ignoring her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel takes in the fresh air, drink in hand. He gazes ou Joyce continues to pace inside. Her harsh words are muffl by the window. Jeff joins his father. They share a quiet moment interrup by the call of a bird.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Hear that? A Red-Eyed Vireo or a Black- Billed Cuckoo. Either way, they only nest in the same place for one year... not entirety. Lionel’s mind goes elsewhere. Jeff seizes the opportunity sneaks a sip of his dad’s scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huddle of SLACKERS chug beers. Figg lights up a joint.

dialogues.speaker: SNARKY SLACKER
dialogues.text: Dude, keep an eye out for Balderelli. That Vice Principal is a freakin’ henchman. Been giving us the hairy eyeball. Hear what he did to Finch?

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Who cares? (passing around a joint) Reefer High Pride, Man. Jeff injects himself in the gathering.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (imitating his father) I need a drink.  47.

dialogues.speaker: SNARKY SLACKER
dialogues.text: Alrighty then... The slacker hands over a beer can-- SNARKY SLACKER (CONT’D) Quick, quick, before the next bell. Jeff gulps it down. RIIING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same pack of slackers & stoners shuffle past Vice Principal Balderelli, who scans for such lowlifes.

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: Blakely, I didn’t forget, we got an appointment during fifth period. Better have your college applications ready to look over. Singer, you too. Balderelli smells alcohol and pot in the air. He reaches and grabs Snarky Slacker on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SNARKY SLACKER
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: What’s the smell, Mr.? As Jeff slides by, under the radar. EXT. NEIL’S FAMILY FARM - BACK YARD/POND - DAY Jeff & Derf follow Neil on a trail, with fishing poles.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: How many acres does your dad have?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I think it’s like fifty or sixty. Was my grandfather’s farm first. The trail opens up to a clearing.

dialogues.speaker: POND
dialogues.text: They sit on the edge of the pond and bait their hooks.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not much of a lake. Hope you guys didn’t hope for more. Next winter we can get a game of ice hockey going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to skate.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Anyhoo, there’s sunfish. Whatever we catch, we gotta toss ‘em back in. They cast in their lines and wait. It’s tranquil.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: You hear about Victor Cramer? His mom caught him masturbating with a vacuum.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What? Is he alright?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: With a vacuum? How?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Supposedly, he stuck his wanker - how else would you masturbate with a vacuum? More time passes...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What’s Helen Keller’s favorite color? Corduroy.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: What’s the difference between parsley and pussy?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: No one eats parsley. Jeff gets a tug on his line.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh... Hey!

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Cool. Ya got one. Reel it in. Jeff REELS IN a pond fish, adding Dahmerisms to the effor for their amusement.

dialogues.speaker: MAAAAAA
dialogues.text: Jeff FLINGS the sunfish to the ground. It FLOPS AROUND at their feet. Jeff leers at it.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Unhook it, before it dies. Here cut the line-- Neil hands over a pocketknife. Jeff kneels down and grips fish. He’s seething, breathing heavily. With one FIERCE STRIKE, Jeff THRUSTS the blade into the f THOK! CHOK! CHUNK! - slicing it open, again, again into a bloody, mutilated mess.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell!?! I said throw ‘em back!! Jeff stares at the bloody knife.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: What’d you do that for?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just wanted to see what it looked like. Bloody fish bits at Jeff's knees. Derf and Neil withdraw, disgusted and baffled by his outburst. Off Jeff, his dark rippling reflection in the pond water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny flirts with Derf, who doodles “Dahmer On The High Seas," a cartoon of Jeff spearfishing for sea monsters. S passes him a note. Derf stops doodling and takes a peak. her phone number. He tucks it away. Jeff enters with a capped Styrofoam cup in hand and plops down at an empty desk nearby. Eyes glazed over.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What’s in the cup?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (rolls back his head) It’s my medicine.  50. Mr. Fedele gets the class’s attention and starts.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: Alright. As you read in Chapter Fifteen, Truman shared the same view of politics as James Madison, a hundred fifty years earlier. Presidential power is the power to persuade in a pluralist world where competing factions mobilize and counter-mobilize. How so? Kent raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: The President must persuade and bargain until policy--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (whispers, about Jeff) Do you smell that?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yeah, he reeks.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (continuing) -- Ultimately arrives at what the typical citizen would want. Jeff sits in a daze, drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff lurks behind some bushes. He drinks from a fifth of vodka. Just around the corner--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf, Kent, Neil, and other members of the Marching Band near an exit door where more band nerds emerge from the B room. They wait for practice to begin.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: If you think about it, we’re one of the few countries not on the metric system. That in itself is a measurement that isolates us from the rest of the world society. It epitomizes our foreign policy.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: You're such a pseudo-intellectual.  51. Jeff emerges from around the corner. He blends in.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Jeff, where’s you trumpet?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I quit.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. Figg swings by on his pot-dealing route.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Hey, posers.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: How’s business?

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Want me to kick your ass? Wanna see something rad?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yeah, show us. Figg reveals a pocket knife.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: My dad used this in Germany.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: He fought the Nazis?

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: No, idiot, he was one. He cut a Jew’s neck with it. Figg slices into the meat of his hand, showing off. No si of pain as the incision bleeds. He sucks on it, then smil for everyone. Blood drips from his teeth like a vampire.  52. Derf, Kent, Neil, and others immediately walk away, disgusted. Figg chuckles. Jeff remains behind, captivated Derf notices and calls back--

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dahmer, C’mon. Stay away from that dude. He’s a psycho-killer, for sure. Jeff runs to catch up to Derf et al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gym class. Coach Natale times students running laps. Seve psycho-stoners and band nerds slowdown to a walk.

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: C’mon boys! Only girls should run ten minute miles. Get your legs moving! On the far side of the track, Jeff trots over to Figg.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Can you keep a secret?

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Depends. Who's asking?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I found a new spot in the woods across the street from my house, it’s deep in, where no one ever goes. Storin’ my road kill. And good place to get high.

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: Pick it up, pick it up!

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Sounds cool. Let’s check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figg drives with a joint in hand. Jeff rides shotgun. “Vi of Changes” from Judas Priest on the 8-track. Figg’s hunt knife rattles around in the console between them.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: All my father plays is the same Neil Sedaka album, over and over again.  53.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: (passing the joint) That sucks.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Take a right at the cemetery onto West Bath Road.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Look! Ahead, a HITCHHIKER sticks out his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s - for a hundred points! Figg drifts the car onto the shoulder, heading straight f the hitchhiker. Jeff stiffens up as they barrel towards h Yet, at the last moment, Figg swerves around the hitchhik cackling to himself. Jeff sighs, relieved. In passing, Je eyes lock on the shaken hitchhiker. Figg takes a sharp turn, cutting off Jeff's stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cruise through a neighborhood. Figg spots a MUTT wandering along the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Even better, ahead for fifty points! Figg guns it. In horror, Jeff covers his face.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Don’t... The Chevette hits the mutt. THUMP! One squeal. It’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figg laughs as the rear tires roll over it. He looks in h rear view mirror and then puts the car in reverse.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Extra points.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Don’t, please.  54.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Oh, C'mon. It’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I said STOP.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Whatever. I’m splitting. Figg speeds away, cranking up the volume on Judas Priest’ jolting “Deceiver.” Jeff's visibly shaken by the incident

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Let me out. Let me out.

dialogues.speaker: FIGG
dialogues.text: Don’t be stupid, you’re gonna show me that spot--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: NO. I’m going home. I’11 cut through. Figg pulls over. Jeff gets out, all riled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figg speeds off. The tires spit gravel back at Jeff. But, his hand is Figg’s knife. Jeff slips into the woods. INT. NEIL’S FAMILY HOME - BASEMENT - NIGHT The Dahmer Fan Club mess around with an 8mm camera. Jeff arrives, happy to see friends. He approaches like a zombi

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: How about we make a zombie movie in your backyard? Call it Ghosts in the Graveyard, or something.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Nah. The camera sucks in low light.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, you were right, Figg’s crazy. But I swiped this off him. Jeff proudly reveals the half-finished joint. INT. NEIL’S FAMILY HOME - BASEMENT - HALF HOUR LATER All are high. They take drags from a dwindling roach.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: ... Derf’s got the hottest mom.  55.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: What? Gross, no way.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Neil’s mom is smokin’, so is the car she drives.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Jaguar, piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Neil’s mom is the hottest.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I banged her, off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yeah right, you did not? They bust up laughing.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: C’mon Kent, haven’t you slept with your best friend’s mom? We all have.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yeah, I have.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I have. In a stoned paranoia, Kent believes them and conforms--

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I have.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: No you haven't.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I did. With Mike’s mom.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Liar. When? Kent pauses, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: C’mon, you haven’t slept with your best friend’s mom, really, have you? They bust up some more.  56.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I wish I had a best friend. Heads turn. Jeff is sitting upright in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Gawd Dahmer, I forgot you were over there. You freaked me out. Jeff forces a laugh, trying to fit in. It’s buzz kill.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Awkward... Okay then. Let’s raid the fridge before my folks get back.

dialogues.speaker: BRRAAAA
dialogues.text: But everyone else is already heading for the stairs. Jeff trails, an insecure tagalong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fans file back to their cars after a football game victor Derf and Kent shed their uniforms & instruments into the trunk of Derf’s Chevy Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf drives in a circle, going round & around.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It’s gonna tip! Tip it, tip it. Hollering. A pure teenage waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf’s Vegas slows down as it passes by Jeff's house.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Are you gonna see if he’s in?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Nah. INT. WHITEY’S BURGER JOINT - DAY Derf, Kent, and Mike play pinball and chow on burgers.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Something about last weekend in Neil’s basement creeped me out. Jeff's a little off. You know?  57.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: But that’s what we like about him.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You think how we treat him is mean?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: What? Why? No.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yeah, he seems to enjoy it. If he didn’t, he wouldn’t do it. Kent, whataya think?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I dunno. Off Derf, as he feverishly flips to save his pinball from going down the gutter. EXT. WHITEY’S BURGER JOINT - PARKING LOT - DAY

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Who's gettin’ the backseat of pain?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE/KENT
dialogues.text: I call shotgun... Kent and Mike race through the parking lot and wrestle fo the front seat of Derf’s car. Mike wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distracted, Jeff pitches a ball to Dave, who chokes up on LOUISVILLE SLUGGER. Dave whiffs, then retrieves the ball. Jeff glances at the road. Jeff pitches again, another whi

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dave, you have to swing through it, like a tennis racquet. No, but with two hands. Give it, let me show you. Jeff takes the baseball bat. He gets in a batter’s stance demonstrate when, out of the corner of his eye, he spots Neighborhood Jogger trotting up the hill. Sparks arousal. Jeff creeps closer to the road, clenches the bat. HUFF! H The jogger approaches. Thigh muscles flex. Chest pounds. Soiled in sweat.  58. Jeff glares at the passing jogger. He unconsciously holds bat upright & erect.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
