dialogues.text: Jeff, what about me? Breaking Jeff's spell. He drops the bat and heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce interrupts Dave doing homework. She gives him kisse a chipper, manipulative manner.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: David, honey, have you thought about what’s wrong with your father? (Dave shakes his head) Well, let me tell you... He’s selfish, he’s unreasonable, he’s-- Compelled to interject, Jeff approaches. Joyce glares at

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why are you being so hard on Dad?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Get away. Has nothing to do with you. Becomes a mother-son stand off. Jeff retreats to his bedr

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave, how would you like to live near Grandma and Grandpa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A local greasy spoon/truck stop. Lionel and his two sons dinner in a booth. Lionel looks stressed. Jeff plays with food, garnering confidence to ask:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Dad? Is Mom going back... to the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She's acting a lot like she did before she went the last time.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: How so?  59.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She never talks to me. Or asks how I’m doing? Am I in her way?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly. So, are there any girls in school that you like?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Mom said she’s moving to Wisconsin to live with Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: She did. When?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: She told me, I dunno. Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Your mother is doing better. I wouldn’t take what she says at face value, but she’s doing much better than before.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Jeff. Derf with his parents - CAROL & RICHARD BACKDERF - and younger brother pass by, headed to the register.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad, this is my friend Dahmer. Jeff Dahmer. Lionel perks up. Parents shake hands, exchanging names.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where’s Mrs. Dahmer?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: She’s home, a bit under the weather.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dad, Jeff's dad is also a chemist.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m at The Firestone. After ten years at The Goodyear.  60.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Really. I’m at the Goodrich Research Center. No longer working on SBRs though.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: New monomers in the mix.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Just spent a year on macrogalleria.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Well, it’s nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Have a good holiday.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Jeff, did you hear? Oliver Zlatka committed suicide two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes, tragic.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: His photo’s in the County Weekly. Richard flashes the front page with OLIVER ZLATKA'’S PHOT

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: A real shame.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I hear... well, it’s hard for some. He was teased, I hear.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I like Oliver. He’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: They live near us. Horrible.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes. Well, anyway, nice to meet you.  61.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: When’s the funeral?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: The paper said the day after Thanksgiving. Regret and sorrow cross Jeff's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff attends the funeral. Graveside as the coffin arrives Jeff finds himself SUDDENLY AROUSED. He covers his erecti in his slacks. He slinks away before the coffin is lowere

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Dave decorate their scrawny Christmas tree. Thei parents fight in the next room--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You should move out in the new year.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’M ALREADY SLEEPING ON THE SOFA.

dialogues.speaker: I WILL TAKE DAVE TO MY MOTHER'S.
dialogues.text: Jeff swells with sadness and leaves the house, unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff gets on his bike and rides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff peddles the moonlit road. Tears run down his face. A buzzes past, blaring its horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff trolls another back road. He rides up to a FROZEN OPOSSUM just lying there. He relishes in the discovery an eagerly pulls a plastic bag from his pocket.  62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff carries his stuffed plastic bag down a narrow trail, leading him deeper into the woods. Jeff arrives at a

dialogues.speaker: SMALL CLEARING
dialogues.text: Hidden among thick brush and tall trees. Jeff lays the de opossum on a rock. He takes out his (stolen) knife and meticulously dissects the road kill, first stripping away flesh, then fondling the entrails in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: JEFF'S FINGERNAILS. Remnants of dried blood underneat his thumbnail. He inconspicuously scrapes it out. It’s the start of the Senior Trip to Washington DC. Jeff laughs, with his Dahmer Fan Club buddies. A more relaxed, relieved glow on his face - a break from home does him go

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: And the Dahmer Fan Club has to leave our mark on DC. Something grand.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Boo-yah, something classic. Like what?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: A spazz on the White House lawn?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You can’t get on the White House lawn. Derf looks around. He lands on CHARLIE SMITH, the one bla student, a burly guy.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Well for one... Charlie, as the token black in our class, let’s get some Super 8 of you on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial giving Martin Luther King’s I Have A Dream speech.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Good one, loser.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: The Dahmer Fan Club will stand behind you like--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: I play football, Backderf, not charades.  63.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Cut!

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Fine, good one. We'll think of something. Jeff notes the brainstorm. He gazes out the window. A hig sign reads: I-70E WASHINGTON and I-76 HARRISBURG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teachers call out pairs of names and hand out room keys.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Jeffrey Dahmer and Charlie Smith, you have Room 327.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie takes the bed by the window. Jeff hesitantly wait the door for Charlie to settle in. From the hallway--

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Dahmer, we're right here. (whispers) If he rapes you in the middle of the night, just knock.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Very funny. Jeff drops his bag on his bed.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, we’re roommates, huh...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Yep. Charlie turns on the TV, switches it to Three’s Company. the clip: Janet sustains Mr. Roper’s belief that Jack is CHARLIE SMITH (CONT’D) So obvious.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Mr. Roper’s an idiot. Taxi’s on ina few.  64. Charlie crosses to the bathroom with his toothbrush. Jeff eyes follow. He pulls off his shirt and watches TV, shirtless. The credits roll. Jeff waits. Charlie returns, though still disinterested in chatting.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m curious... is it hard being the only black kid in our class?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE SMITH
dialogues.text: Ehh.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Your palms are less black. You think your insides are the same color as mine? Is my stomach and your stomach the same color? Charlie gives Jeff an intimidating stare, silencing the chitchat. Charlie lays supine on his bed as Taxi starts. sneaks a couple glances at his built body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE as Jeff AND HIS SENIOR CLASS approach the WASHING MONUMENT. Neil photographs Derf on his back - the landmar his erection. They scale THE CAPITOL BUILDING steps where Jeff throws a quick spazz. They line THE WHITE HOUSE fence, like jailbirds.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: Kids, since World War Two, public access to The White House grounds has been increasingly restricted. But maybe you can see President Carter through a window.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Let us in! Let me in! Nearby, a cluster of protestors hold up signs: No Nukes, Needs Oil? I Ride The Bus, Don’t Trust The Shah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and his pals play poker, and chow on soda and snacks Jeff wins the hand.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Damn, Dahmer. Thought you had nothin’.  65.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: He’s got a poker face.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Beginner's luck, I guess. Neil deals another hand.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dahmer, Man of Mystery. Totally my next cartoon. Jeff smiles, enjoying the camaraderie. It’s good to be aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff, Derf, Penny, and Neil stroll along Constitutional A

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Totally bogus we didn’t meet the President. Could’ve met our State Senators back in Ohio, you know?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Let's call Carter, see if he’s free.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: That’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: How about Vice President Mondale? Jeff heads to the nearest pay phone stall. He steps insid Derf follows, amused.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into pay phone) Hi. Yes, I’d like the number for the Vice President of The United States. His office number, please. Derf chuckles. Neil and Penny idle by, skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: This is pointless. It’s our last day here, we should get lunch... Jeff talks on the phone. Derf gestures to Penny & Neil.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: It’s ringing.  66. Jeff starts talking--

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s talking to an Aide. Derf leans in to listen--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (into phone) ... And we’re from Revere High in Ohio, just in the middle of nowhere, and my friends and I are honor students and on the school newspaper, and we're all very interested in politics, and I was wondering if we could interview you on what it’s like to work as an aide to the Vice President of The United States. (listens) Uh, huh. Sure. We’re on Constitutional Avenue. Uh, huh. Great. Jeff hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're in.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What? C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dahmer’s got balls, man. He’s slick.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We have an appointment in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AIDE gives Jeff, Derf, Neil, and Penny a tour.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And you get to sit in meetings with the Vice President?

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Really? Where’s his office.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Down that hall. Let’s see if he’s in.  67. INT. VICE PRESIDENT WALTER MONDALE’S OFFICE - DAY VICE PRESIDENT WALTER MONDALE reviews documents with a Cabinet Member. The teens wait in a line near the door, nervous. The Vice President approaches.

dialogues.speaker: VP WALTER MONDALE
dialogues.text: Kids, thanks for dropping by. I have a moment before a call with Indira Gandhi, who just resigned as Prime Minister of India. Where are you from? Jeff's heart pounds, in awe. VP WALTER MONDALE (CONT’D) Ohio’s a great state. So, what do each of you want to be when you grow up? The Vice President looks to Derf.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I, like, want to draw cartoons, not for TV. I want to draw comics, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VP WALTER MONDALE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s great, as long as you don’t draw any political ones making fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Of course not. Jeff stiffens. The Vice President finally reaches him--

dialogues.speaker: VP WALTER MONDALE
dialogues.text: And so, what interests you? All heads turn. His friends are curious, as well.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Biology.

dialogues.speaker: VP WALTER MONDALE
dialogues.text: Great. You should pursue that. The Vice President shakes Jeff's clean hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They race away from the building, soaring and giddy. They gratefully pat Jeff on the back.  68.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: That was the coolest thing I’ve ever done in my life. I can die now. Dahmer, I can die now, thank you. Jeff basks in their congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus rumbles into the Revere High parking lot as the t reaches it’s definitive end. Out the window, parents eage await the return of their kids. Despondent over the retur grave curtain of darkness returns to Jeff's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sulks back to his father’s car.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You have a good time? Y’alright?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. It was great.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You don’t look well. You have a fever?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A converted living room lined with chairs. Two children babble and play, just beyond arm’s length of their mother The kids suck on new lollipops.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Careful. The mother makes departing small talk and leaves with her kids. A NURSE appears with a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Jeffrey Dahmer. ANGLE ON Jeff Dahmer seated against the far wall.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s me. The nurse shuffles down a hallway. He follows.  69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff waits, seated on the examination table in his underw He looks around at the cabinets, jars of cotton balls and gauze, the weight scale, the eye chart. Dr. York enters, sucking on a lollipop - it’s the Neighborhood Jogger at work. He glances at the clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Are you running a cold?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (represses his excitement) I think so. I’ve been getting chills.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Always nice to see new patients.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: A physical, maybe? Jeff stiffens as Dr. York moves in, on his swivel chair.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Stick out your tongue. Say Ahhh.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Abhhh.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Tonsils look good. Turn. Let me see your ears...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Do you do surgery?

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: I like caring for patients but I’m not the type to wanna cut someone open. So this, but almost became a podiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Less blood.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Exactly.  70.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What about what’s on a patient’s mind?

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: You mean, a psychiatrist?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: My mom had one. Dr. York puts his stethoscope against Jeff's chest and ba Jeff fights his quick breathing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: So far, you look healthy. Okay, before I weigh you. Do you hurt when you pee?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Huh? No.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: Are you sexually active?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What kind, sort of...

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER
dialogues.text: You’re at the age. No growths, okay. Pull down your underwear. Jeff pulls down his underwear.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cough. Cough again. Cough again. Suddenly, a stalled silence. He returns to his clipboard. awkward tension between them, implies Jeff became erect.

dialogues.speaker: DR. YORK/NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pull up your pants, I’m finished. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Standing in the same position, Jeff finishes jerking off. KNOCK. Another KNOCK.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just a minute, go away, just a minute. He sharpens up and pulls up his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dahmer Family rush out of the house. Lionel and the b are in suits, Joyce in a dress. They scramble into a car.  71.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Remember, please, behave yourself. It’s my boss and work associates--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Boys, he doesn’t even know the groom.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: It’s my boss’s son, which is all the same. Kids, there’1l be some other kids there your age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s cocktail hour. Jeff approaches the bar.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: My Dad wants a Jack and coke.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (distrustful) Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Over there.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: On the other side... I swear... He spots Joyce slipping out with a sleazy PERENNIAL BACHE

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Sorry, kid, he’ll have to come get it himself. Jeff leaves the bar, then swipes an almost empty cocktail glass from a busboy’s tray.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Jeff sits, sober, with his father and brother.

dialogues.speaker: COWORKER
dialogues.text: Lionel, and where’s your wife?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: She's, uh, not feeling well. Headache. Went to rest in the car.  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel finds Joyce fixing her makeup in a hallway mirror. Perennial Bachelor idles feet away.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Dinner was served a half hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I was fucking that guy over there. The Perennial Bachelor slips back into the party, avoidin

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s your boss’s cousin, staying here at the hotel. I might just stay the night. If you won’t divorce me, then deal with it. Lionel swallows his pride and anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, at home, he furiously packs two suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’ve had enough. You’re a mess and impossible... I’m done with you.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Good. Lionel storms out. Jeff follows, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel reverses out of the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Don’t, dad, don’t...

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Finally. Jeff runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff stumbles through the woods, unraveling, agonizing. H WHACKS a fallen branch against a tree repeatedly... drain himself. The sound travels... A KITCHEN LIGHT turns on.  73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff WHACKS tennis balls in every direction, spazzing out his teammates. Neil stops rallying to watch.

dialogues.speaker: TENNIS COACH
dialogues.text: Jeff Dahmer, if you don’t clean up your act, you’re off the team. Jeff stops. He drops his racquet and WALKS OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff pounds a fifth of gin in no time. Slurps the last dr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dahmer Fan Club hangs around Derf’s Chevy Vegas, listening to Buzzard Radio 101 WMMS. Jeff shuffles by.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Dahmer. Dahmier, boy. Wanna hang?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: How about later? Whitey’s for burgers and arcade - they just got Death Race.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Nah. Jeff veers away, disengaging...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balderelli polices the main thoroughfare. With cunning, J avoids and staggers by, gripping his leather briefcase, t BUMPS into two students. They smell the alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Dang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a dark room, a corny 1960s 16mm anti-drug educational unspools for students. MR. LAPOLLA monitors the projector

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE BOY ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: I’m glad I didn’t jump off that bridge. It’s much higher than it looked.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: I really think you should talk to someone. LSD is dangerous.  74.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR FOR FILM
dialogues.text: Most young people think they’re stronger and have more willpower than they actually do. Jeff opens the door, tries to slip in undetected--

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAPOLLA
dialogues.text: You're late, Mr. Dahmer. Again.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR FOR FILM
dialogues.text: And one of the potentials for drug traffic is the school. Jeff trips over a student in the front row.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Watch it, Jerk! (smells Jeff's boozy breath) Yuck, arrr, Damn.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: S-S-Sorry. Disoriented, Jeff BLOCKS THE LIGHT from the projector. Blinded, he struggles to find a path to an empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR FOR FILM
dialogues.text: Here the connection can be found with these peddlers of misery who prey on the unwary, the uninformed, the curious, the thrill-seekers...

dialogues.speaker: MR. LAPOLLA
dialogues.text: Move it, Dahmer, get a seat!

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR FOR FILM
dialogues.text: ++. Most young people will continue through life as normal, responsible citizens. Others, the shunted and unloved, are the candidates for the slave world of lifelong drug addiction. Jeff drops into a chair, and lowers his sad, lonely face. NARRATOR FOR FILM (CONT’D) But no-one is immune. How does it happen? Where does it start? What are the signs?  75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huddled cluster of upperclassmen get high and drink, al with one youthful teacher, MR. PITT. Passing around a joi

dialogues.speaker: SNARKY SLACKER
dialogues.text: You blow up some gooks?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PITT
dialogues.text: If I told you, I’d have to kill you too.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STONER
dialogues.text: Awesome. C’mon. Nearby, Jeff drinks by his lonesome. His stash and finish bottles are tucked under a log.

dialogues.speaker: SNARKY SLACKER
dialogues.text: Shit, dude, look, Balderelli. Heads turn. In the distance, Vice Principal Balderelli crosses the practice field, approaching.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STONER
dialogues.text: Run. The stoners and Mr. Pitt scatter. Jeff doesn’t freak out just lies down behind the log, playing dead. Balderelli steps into the woods and looks around. Smells pot and goes further in... ducking under branches. He pas right by Jeff, but doesn’t see him. Then, spots a couple stoners making a run for it across the practice field.

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: Hey, I SEE YOU. STOP RIGHT THERE. Balderelli storms out of the woods and chases them down. sits back up and continues drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drafts of the yearbook layout are pinned to a bulletin bo Derf, Neil, and Mike enthusiastically rush in.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: It’s here!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Dahmer’s got to see this. We should get him. Neil, see if he’s around.  76. Yet, they cannot contain themselves and rip open the pack They spread out the developed club photos. Laughter swell over sight of Jeff's face in many.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: .-. And here he is again!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So bad, it’s so bad! Their YEARBOOK ADVISOR enters. She’s a snippy woman.

dialogues.speaker: YEARBOOK ADVISOR
dialogues.text: Good, they came in. Let’s see. She scans the photos, realizing the prank. YEARBOOK ADVISOR (CONT’D) What is Jeff Dahmer - he’s not in any of these clubs. Who did this?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: He’s not?

dialogues.speaker: YEARBOOK ADVISOR
dialogues.text: He doesn’t belong in Debate or here or this one. She grabs a wide black marker and BLOTCHES OUT JEFF’S FAC all the club photos, a fitting symbol. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE'’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Jeff stares at the wall, mouthing the lyrics to Black Sabbath’s “Iron Man” playing on his cassette player.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SABBATH LYRICS
dialogues.text: Is he alive or dead? Has he thoughts within his head? We'll just pass him there, Why should we even care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce is deeply absorbed on the phone. Jeff approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Is he out of his mind? I can’t believe that’s his position. He’s being completely irrational.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mom.  77.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (into phone) There’s no way I'd give custody of Dave over. Never in a million years.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (to Jeff) Shhh. (back to phone) He’s g-g-getting everything. I’M NOT BEING IRRATIONAL. YOU HEAR ME? YOU’RE MY LAWYER, NOT HIS. DAYS? I WON’T DISCUSS HIS CUSTODY. Jeff swipes hot dogs from the fridge and slinks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lurking in the bushes, Jeff lures Wendy Watkins’ Irish Se over to him with his raw hot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Good dog. Jeff unlatches the dog from its run line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff leads the dog to the same spot where he once tore ap the frozen opossum. Jeff takes out his knife. His teeth chatter, readying for the kill. The dog sits, panting, wagging its tail. Jeff approaches, knife in hand. He pulls the dog to his SLAUGHTER ROCK, where remnants of rodent skulls are scatt around. The dog yaps. Its tail continues to wag. But, at the last moment... Jeff cannot do it. He TOSSES the knife aside.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Go on! Go! Go home. Get! The dog runs off. Jeff drops to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Fedele takes attendance. He notes Jeff’s absence.  78.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: Mr. Jeff Dahmer, absent again. That’s five times in the last two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: (whispers) We need our mascot back... Life’s not as much fun around here.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Maybe we should just let him be, you know? He’s not--

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: C'mon, Neil. It’s all - he likes the attention.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Maybe so. But... Neil keeps his thoughts to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff finishes the last drop from a fifth of vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents hurriedly pick up their kids from after-school practices & rehearsals. They pass Jeff slouched on the fr steps, sobering up.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT
dialogues.text: Mr. Dahmer, another long day hitting the books?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yep. He turns away to conceal his sozzled self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her Oldsmobile Omega, Joyce pulls into a parking spot. Dave sits in the passenger seat. Jeff sits in the back. Lionel’s already there, waiting by his car.  79.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Just a minute, before you spend the day with your father, I need to talk to him. Stay in the car. Joyce takes a set of legal documents and gets out. Jeff quickly steals some loose cash from her purse. Both sons hear something, and look out the rear window. T watch in stunned paralysis as: Joyce and Lionel get in each other’s faces, talking forcefully. Joyce waves the legal papers in the air. Suddenly, Joyce blows her lid. She shoves Lionel. She sla at him, yelling. Retaliating, veins pop out of Lionel’s n He holds her arms down. She kicks him. He kicks her back. shoves her away. She runs right back at him, flailing her arms, losing papers to the ground. RANDOM ADULTS rush over to break it up. They separate Joy and Lionel. Joyce is crying, and threatening him. All wor are muffled inside the car as the kids watch, helpless. Joyce returns to the car, fuming. She rummages for her ke She pulls out in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I thought we were going to see Daddy. Jeff glares at his mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff buys more alcohol from a HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUT.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUT
dialogues.text: You’re my best customer. Jeff takes the large bottle of vodka and drops it into hi leather briefcase, revealing how he transports it undetec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rows of parked cars. It’s quiet with class in session. Co Natale wanders through on a cigarette break and discovers Jeff behind a car drinking.

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: Hey! What’s this? On school grounds. What’s your name?  80.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: J-Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: What do you have to say for yourself?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (puts on an act) It’s just... My parents are splitting up and I’m pretty depressed about it and I thought drinking might help--

dialogues.speaker: COACH NATALE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about your folks-- INT. VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: But that’s no excuse. It’s not as bad as it seems.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Little late for that.

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: It’s no excuse, period. Here’s the deal. You have a choice. I can either phone your parents and tell them what you did or you can take ten licks and not drink again. Your call.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Don’t call my parents.

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: Your choice... ooookay. Balderelli pulls a paddle from his desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI
dialogues.text: Bend over and grab the wall. Jeff's stunned. He puts his hands on the wall. Balderelli winds up and WHACKS Jeff in the ass. Jeff drops to his kn VICE PRINCIPAL BALDERELLI (CONT’D) Get up. He returns to his position and receives a paddling. Each strike is worse than the last.  81. INT. DAHMER FAMILY HOME - JEFF & DAVE’S BEDROOM - THAT NI Alone, Jeff paces. A sore limp from the paddling lingers. swirl of depraved thoughts, his dismantling family, his o inner-disgust brings him to tears. Haunted:

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Okay... alright... okay... alright... Tears slide down his face. He drops onto his bed and curl beside the DEAD NEIGHBORHOOD JOGGER, stiff and speechless Jeff finds comfort. Jeff holds the dead jogger tight.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mutters) Don’t leave me, don’t leave me. CUT TO WIDE SHOT of Jeff in bed alone. The dead Neighborh Jogger is a fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf doodles a cartoon of Dahmer in his notebook. Class discussion of Faulkner's As I Lay Dying is background noi TAP TAP on the window gets his attention. Outside the win Jeff POPS his head up and GROWLS at him. Derf chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH TEACHER
dialogues.text: Mr. Backderf. Are you with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A field party. Bully-jocks, Psycho-Stoners, Band Nerds ar all there. Beer cans. Making out. The Dahmer Fan Club shotgun beers. Several Bully-Jocks impose:

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: Look, the Rah Rah band nerds drink.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatdya you think, we’d?--

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK NUMBSKULL
dialogues.text: Lightweights--

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: Be home playin’ snare drum.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK DICKWAD
dialogues.text: Snap.  82.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: More active than standing on the sidelines.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Dang.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: Good one. Y’alright for a turd. Where’s your mascot, Dumb Dahmer?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: He’s not here--

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: He gonna be your prom date, Backderf?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Your mother might, if she can fit ina dress.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: Dahmer’s like your little court jester. ‘Cept he’s not hangin’ with you much anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: The fan club lives on.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: Really? Looks like he ditched ya.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Just think he’s confused--

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK NUMBSKULL
dialogues.text: And looks like Neil’s a little protective.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: And passing out cartoon flyers is getting kinda old, don’t ya think?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: He’s still into it.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: I dunno. Seems like you’re closing out your high school career shucked by the fool.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK NUMBSKULL
dialogues.text: Makes you the fools that you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get him to show up.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Uh. A rockin’ command performance. He’1ll ante up. For sure.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK DICKWAD
dialogues.text: Doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: (aside, to Kent & Mike) Let’s just do it. Let’s get him to take his spazz to the max--

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Derf, he’s hasn't spazzed in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: He’s not really interested in a whole lot anymore. Better not--

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yeah but, what if we pay him? I’11l put in five bucks. (drops cash in his cap) Gets ‘em out on a Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I’m in. It‘’1l be killer.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He’1l surely blow it on booze.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: (to Neil) C’mon, man, put in some. I’m taking a pot.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, for his booze fund. Neil shakes his head, disapproving.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Nuh-uh.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Chill, Neil. Bully-Jock Jerkoff pays in. 83.  84.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY-JOCK JERKOFF
dialogues.text: I'll believe it when I see it. Derf and Mike start to circulate, selling more tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf stops Jeff in his stuporous path. Jeff bleeps, BRAAA

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Hey, Jeff. So, look, we got an idea for the Fan Club... Onlooking, Neil steps away, remarks--

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (to Kent) We should just leave him alone. He’s not a side show attraction. BACK TO Derf, wrapping up his plan with Jeff--

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Great. Here’s thirty-two bucks. It’1l be your Command Performance. We might have more by Saturday. Jeff nods, half-coherent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf and Kent arrive in the Chevy Vegas. They head to the kitchen door and knock. Jeff opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Gweeetings.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just a sec. Jeff heads back to retrieve something. Derf and Kent deci to tiptoe into the house.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Where’s that pink foot stool? They head through the kitchen and discover depressive Joy Dahmer slouched over at the dining room table, quivering.  85.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Hiii boyzzzz. Derf and Kent stiffen up. The pink foot stool is tipped o on its side, abandoned in corner.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Ready? Jeff is in the kitchen, with a jacket draped over a paper grocery bag, under his arm. Derf and Kent follow him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s drizzling. The worn wipers stutter across the windshield. Derf drives with Kent in the passenger seat. sits in the back, straddling the center hump.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: (glances in rearview mirror) You’re blocking my view. Sit on either side, Dahmer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m good. Jeff pulls a six-pack of Busch beer from the paper bag. H pops open a can and flauntingly gulps it down like water. crushes the can and drops it on the floor, then repeats. uncomfortable to watch, so they chatter:

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Is Cooper coming?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: He said he was.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: And what about Borowski and Guentlzer?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Guentlzer is but Borowski didn’t pay. We'll see who in ten minutes. Derf peeks in the rear view mirror. Jeff pounds another b then another. His “aura of doom” makes Derf twinge.

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never seen ya drink like that before, Dahmer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, here I am.  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull into the Summit Mall Parking lot. Jeff burps in backseat, already finished with his beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a daze, Jeff follows Derf and Kent to the main entranc

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Where we meeting these idiots?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Right in front of the Orange Julius.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m psyched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf and Kent, with Jeff trailing, spot the pack of paid SPECTATORS, numbering nearly a dozen upperclassmen.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: ‘Bout time! (hands Jeff cash) Another fifteen bucks. Not bad. Jeff stuffs the cash in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Ok. Let’s do this. One teenager pulls out an 8mm camera. Others start commen and snickering with anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We present Jeff--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Jeffrey. For this I’m Jeffrey.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: The Dahmer Fan Club presents Jeffrey Dahmer in his Command Performance. Derf pats Jeff on the back, gesturing forward...

dialogues.speaker: DERF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers in Jeff's ear) Welcome to the wild world of wasteful capitalism. Why don’t you show them what it’s all about?  87.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Glllaaaaaaadddd-11lleeee. Jeff walks down the main shopping hallway toward innocent shoppers. The teenage pack trail him at a distance. And like its origins in the high school hallway, Jeff thr an EPIC EPILEPTIC-LIKE SPAZZ, flailing his arms and legs.

dialogues.speaker: BAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
dialogues.text: Unsuspecting SHOPPERS turn heads, spooking many. Some scu away with children. The teenage-pack roars with laughter, snorting, falling over each other.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENAGE-PACK
dialogues.text: Oh, Man! That was awesome. Where is he? Boo-yah. Over there? Get closer. Jeff chases THREE MIDDLE-SCHOOL GIRLS, moaning and grunti in their wake. The girls dip into the bathroom for safety THE TEENAGE-PACK (CONT’D) Did you get that on camera? Jeff continues plodding through the mall, spooking more a more shoppers with flares of fits--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh! Uh! Uh! Uh! UUUUUUUUH! A mother grabs her child. An elderly couple scurry into a clothing store. Jeff approaches a FOOD CLERK passing out free samples. He takes two handfuls in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are these?

dialogues.speaker: FOOD CLERK
dialogues.text: Toasted sunflower seeds. Jeff SPITS THEM OUT EVERYWHERE--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: PFFFFFFFT. I’m allergic, I’m allergic... AAHHHHHH --BUCKING AND RETCHING as he scampers away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff approaches STOUFFER’S RESTAURANT, the main dining sp He startles diners in a front table, then knocks over dri at the next and slams his hands - SPLAT - into their food Jeff shudders into the restaurant, spazzing down the aisl

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Burrrrrlmannnnn? Mr. Burlmannnn where are you? Where’s my stooooool?

dialogues.speaker: RESTAURANT MANAGER
dialogues.text: Hey, kid, get out-- Jeff responds with a ROARING SPAZZ, scaring all the diner RESTAURANT MANAGER (CONT’D) OUT - OUT. LEAVE. The teenage-pack howl with laughter, bringing many to tea The Restaurant Manager chases Jeff out. Jeff writhes his through the tables, avoiding the manager on his way out.. MONTAGE as Jeff continues his romp in & out of more store - JEFF POPS up from behind a clothing rack, scares mother daughter. - JEFF CREEPS OUT a gaggle of girls entering the cinema. - JEFF CONVULSES at the feet of a family.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mommmmmmm, Mommmmmmm, Urrrrr, Mommmm. Leads to an anticlimactic end... The group’s interest has dwindled. They start to break apart as Jeff's final, wani fit barely causes a reaction from a passing shopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teenage pack lingers, chitchat about next activities encircles Jeff, who’s seemingly discarded.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: ... how about Rocky Horror? Derf is the only one who senses Jeff's exclusion.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: (obligatory) That was dope, Dahmer. But, no response. His hollow core dumps a sourness on Der  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s still raining. Derf and Kent head to the car. Jeff shuffles behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff stews in the backseat, a clenched fist. Derf’s punk plays on his stereo. It’s Electric Eels’ “Agitated.”

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Or head into Akron, check out The Bank, that new punk club? Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You're alone in this punk stuff, Derf.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: It’s a revolution of the American dream gone bust. What could be more enlightening and unsettling at the same time?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. A strained silence.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I missed the turn onto Granger, so I‘1l just take the left on West Bath back to your place. Okay, Dahmer?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’1l go to The Bank, bang some heads around.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I’m not sure if we’re--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (mumbles ) You’re welcome. Something. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You alright, dude?  Jeff Derf seat 90.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just let me out. Why not drag me along? Let me out.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I’m gonna drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Pull over. Fuck. Dickheads. HITS the back of Kent’s seat.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Whoa. pulls his car over onto the shoulder. Jeff pushes Kent’s forward before the car comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Chill, chill. BLOWS his lid. Jeff Kent Jeff Jeff

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Out, let me out. opens his door and steps out to make Jeff's exit easier.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: What’s the stink?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: The Dahmer Fuckin’ Fan Club. kicks the door, then the side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yo! pounds the roof. Derf bursts out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why’d they make me do that?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You. Them. Everyone. Thanks for nothing.  91.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You got fifty bucks, dude.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No no no no. You don’t get it. Don’t get it. You don’t get it. Forget it. I thought you guys had my back.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: We do, Dahmer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That you were my friends. Jeff jumps at Kent, an awkward mix of a punch and hug. An animalistic, askew moment. Kent wiggles away as Derf jump to pull them apart. It’s such an odd moment that both Der and Kent laugh it off, which unintentionally makes it wor for Jeff. Derf and Kent withdraw to the car, unsure what to do next Jeff catches his breath, wipes his runny nose.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you Dahmer?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Get out of here. BRAAAA. Go. Derf and Kent get back in the Chevy Vegas. The ignition stutters before finally turning over.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Bye, dude. They drive off. Jeff is left in the rain, deeply desponde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff enters, sopping wet. A hollow shell of his former se Joyce is there, uncommonly joyful and bright.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (listening, on phone) Uh huh, uh huh, great. That’s great news. I will. Tomorrow, first thing. Joyce hangs up. She turns to Jeff.  92.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great news. The divorce is finalized.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: And I need you to promise to keep a secret from your father. I’m moving back to Wisconsin with your brother.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: As soon as possible. Your dad is getting the house. And you can’t tell your dad I’m doing this. Promise me you won’t tell. (strained pause) Promise me, Jeff. Jeffrey.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I won't, I won’t tell. Joyce walks away. He slinks back to his bedroom where the baseball bat waits, leaning in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff hides in the bushes with the baseball bat, anxious. peaks out. Dr. York/Neighborhood Jogger is approaching. J recoils into the bushes. His eyes beam with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: Dr. York’s running sneakers grip the pavement. Muscles flexing. Sweat dripping down his face. Jeff TIGHTENS HIS GRIP on his bat. Anticipation whets his appetite. Will this be his first kill? He edges out... Just then-- Joyce Dahmer pulls into the driveway in her Oldsmobile Om Dr. York runs by, saved by the interruption. Jeff keels o simmering and unfulfilled. Joyce pulls shopping bags from the trunk, then notices Je tangled in the bushes.  93.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I’m not washing those jeans again. Just went shopping for the last time, too tired to make dinner. I’m done making dinner for this family. She heads inside. Jeff's tumultuous mood turns to rage. Baseball bat still in grip, he eyes the car. He winds up, then beats the nearest tree trunk, roaring:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a beautiful spring day. TWO KIDS, nearly 14 years innocent, stroll on a trail. They come around a bend and discover a DOG SKULL perched stick. Flies encircle - it’s a recent kill. Nearby, the MUTILATED DOG CARCASS is nailed to a tree trunk. Horrified, the kids run off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students toss a frisbee, enjoying a beautiful day at the of the school year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf and Mike play chess.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not a surprise, but I heard you asked Penny to the prom.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yep. Been sorta on the down low.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yeah, like non existent.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Like overdue.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Like none of your bees wax. Check.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Heard she asked you.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: No. Actually, checkmate.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Shoot. Who am I gonna invite? They head to the exit door.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not that I really wanna go--

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I heard two kids found a dead dog in the woods, behind Bath Church.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Really. Crazy.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, my neighbor and a friend found ‘em. The kids freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I bet it’s a coven of witches.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Coven of witches?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Totally. If you read, there’s a rise in satanic cults. I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: That’s whack. Mike, maybe you can ask them to make a wish in their cauldron to get you a prom date.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Buzz off. Jeff comes from around the bushes and slinks past.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Dahmer. Mike’s looking for a date. Jeff stares at all of them, more distant. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Derf’s putting you up for Prom King.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: No we’re not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn’t a girl within fifty miles that would go to prom with Dahmer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No? The comment stings. Jeff stares down Mike.
Jeff stops BRIDGET, a meek sophomore, on her way to class uncharacteristically turns on his social charm.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Bridget. Hi. You got a second?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I was heading to French class.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well... I know we don’t know each other too well.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But I heard your friend Margaret is going to the prom.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Yeah, with Brian Guentlzer. They're friends from Debate.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What are you doing Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Some final papers are due.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, what about going to the prom?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh. With who?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh. I dunno.  96.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You could join her. And go with me.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I’m gonna be late.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It’ll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You're not gonna be weird or drink?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I promise, I won’t. Look, barely any upperclassmen know you but if you go to the prom, you’ll be way ahead of most girls in your class. You wanna seem normal, right?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: So many freshman just wish they could be asked. It’s totally normal that I thought of you.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I dunno, can I think about it? Let me ask my parents. Flattered, Bridget scurries away. Jeff smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prom Night. “Stairway To Heaven” theme, with balloons clustered together like clouds. Derf & Penny mingle with and Neil and their dates. The boys are uncomfortable in rented tuxedoes, and with the pressure of a dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Where’s Mike?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: He couldn't get a date, I guess. Wimp.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff arrives with Bridget. He’s sober. He’s forgone traditional prom attire and instead wears brown slacks, a vest, and a western-style bow tie. Bridget is draped in a long-sleeve, white dress. She seems tentative around him. They immediately encounter the PROM PHOTOGRAPHER, who's starting to break-down his equipment.

dialogues.speaker: PROM PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Step in front of the back drop. You're my last of the night. Jeff and Bridget pose stiffly next to each other.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You promised me you won’t drink. I told my dad you're a friend.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: PROM PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Get closer. Don’t be scared, she’s not going to bite. Jeff shimmies closer and puts his arm around her, awkward

dialogues.speaker: PROM PHOTOGRAPHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smile. Bridget smiles. Click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff and Bridget enter the prom. Many dance to “I Love Th Nightlife.” Derf and his buddies idle in the back.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Look who's here. Unbelievable. Derf and his buddies observe as Jeff & Bridget make their through the space: Jeff finds her a seat and retrieves punch. She’s charmed.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Thank you. That’s sweet.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I try. Neil approaches.  98.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Dahmer. Hey. Good to see you here. Uh, hey, I feel bad. Wanna apologize for the mall, dude.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You weren’t there.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I know. I couldn’t... You know, you didn’t have to...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It wasn’t bad.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yeah? I don’t know... I’m sorry. The music shifts to “Hopelessly Devoted To You” as Neil’s date tugs on his arm. Neil withdraws, apology unfinished. Jeff stews. He looks around at the cruel clusters of cliq Silencing his naysayers, Jeff leads Bridget to the dance floor, increasingly uneasy. Sweat dots his forehead. Jeff and Bridget dance, a bit out-of-sync with each other But she enjoys herself. Copying couples around them, she places both arms around his neck. He turns rigid.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to put your hands around my waist. Jeff follows her order. And grows more uncomfortable by h closeness. Her slight femininity is unpleasant to him. Their presence on the dance floor pressures Derf, Kent, a Neil to lead their dates there as well, joining in the discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m Penny.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Bridget.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Hey, Jeff, good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (muddled) Congratulations.  99.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: We made it.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Huh? They all continue to dance, but Jeff's composure is slipp The cramped dance floor, bouncing heads, loud music, his sober alertness, all compounds. He draws back.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (into Bridget’s ear) I‘ll be right back. Gotta pee.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Bridget remains dancing, now without a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff passes by the bathroom and walks out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget stops dancing, now lost among the mess. She looks around. Circulates among the tables, growing increasingly upset. Jeff's nowhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff sits stone-faced in his AMC Pacer, eating a Big Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visibly upset, Bridget hunches over in a chair sniveling. pack of girls console her, now ignoring their dates. And, most everyone at the prom is wondering:

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Where’s Dahmer?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: He’s not in the men’s room.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It’s rude.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Seriously, I’m not surprised.  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff returns. PARENT/CHAPERONE stands in his way.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT /CHAPERONE
dialogues.text: Where do you think you’re going? You can’t go back in?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: PARENT /CHAPERONE
dialogues.text: Once you’ve left. You’ve been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I haven't. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT /CHAPERONE
dialogues.text: Rules are rules, young man. Jeff steps away. Disappointed. Dejected. But determined t see the night through, he waits in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prom lets out. Bridget’s leaving with friends. Jeff approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I’m not talking to you. They’re taking me home.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Wait, no. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Where’d you go?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Look, they wouldn’t let me back in but I didn’t drink. I just stepped out to get fresh air and it’s not my fault.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: This is the worst night of my life.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Let me make it up to you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Please. I meant for you to have a nice evening.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: How? The prom’s over. Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But, but, I promised your dad I'd bring you home safe. I promised him. Bridget stops in her tracks, now feels guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff drives Bridget home. Jeff breaks the silence--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Did everyone wonder where I was?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Yeah. So?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Good. EXT. BRIDGET’S HOME - DRIVEWAY - NIGHT Like a gentleman, Jeff opens the car door for Bridget and walks her to the door. She waits, as any confused young g might, for an obligatory kiss. Jeff shakes her hand, stif

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Good night. Abruptly, and awkwardly, ending the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf and Mike sit with their eyes locked on the clock. Th minute hand clicks toward 3:15pm--

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Five, four, THREE, TWO, ONE! THE FINAL BELL RINGS. They burst out of their seats.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FEDELE
dialogues.text: Have a good summer kids. Best of luck in college.  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students tear out of the school, tossing notebooks in the air. Revere High sign reads: CONGRATULATIONS SENIORS GOOD

dialogues.speaker: LUCK
dialogues.text: Derf, Kent, Mike, and Neil pile into the Chevy Vegas. The blast WMMS FM, which fittingly plays Queen’s “We Are The Champions.” Penny and girlfriends jump into another car t follow them out. Meanwhile, Jeff drags his feet and files onto a school bu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff walks by jubilant underclassmen and sits in the back row. A sullen pout. His one safe haven has just ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus stops. The last passengers file off.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Hey, kid. Last stop. Jeff trudges off the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff walks up the hill, approaching his home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff finds his mother Joyce hurriedly stuffing her last couple of suitcases and boxes into the Oldsmobile Omega.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mom, you're gonna miss my graduation ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Your father will be there. We can’t be at the same place.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Can I go?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: No, you'll already be in Wisconsin with me and grandma. Get in.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Now?  103. Joyce and Dave get in and reverse out. Dave waves, naivel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff walks into the deathly silent house. Empty drawers. Missing furniture. Yet, there’s the pink foot stool. Tipp over and forgotten. He takes it in his hands and BASHES i into pieces against the brick fireplace. Leads him to collapse face down on the floor. A flood of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately after the graduation ceremony. A congratulato mood. Lionel hands his camera to another father and asks a photo of him with Jeff, wearing cap & gown. Lionel smil proudly. Jeff is blank. INT. BACKDERF FAMILY HOME - DERF’S BEDROOM - EVENING Derf stuffs his clothes into a duffel bag. Then shoves in more random items, quickly realizing he’s missing somethi

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Mom, I‘1l be right back. Gotta grab some things at the store.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: But be back soon. I’m just about to put your favorite Hawaiian chicken in the oven.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: And pick up my last paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We're sitting down, the whole family, in little over an hour.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Okay. Gotcha. Derf bursts out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exiting with a grocery bag of odds & ends, Derf waves bac some fellow coworkers at the registers. He jumps back in car and speeds off.  104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Windows down. Wind in the hair. Listening to Devo’s rendi of “[I Can't Get No] Satisfaction,” Derf cruises the curv back roads of his hometown for one last evening. Coming around a turn, his headlights catch a figure walki on the side of the road. It’s Jeff. Derf pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Jeff. Hey, man.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Gweeetings! Baaa.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Ha. Wanna ride? Headed home?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Sure. Jeff gets in.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I was taking the long way. I leave tomorrow morning for college. Taking some summer classes.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf and Jeff pull into the driveway. The house is comple dark. Not even a light over the front door.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Wanna come in?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Geez, your house is dark.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got it to myself. My dad’s living with his girlfriend and my mom’s gone to Milwaukee with my brother.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Are you bleeding?  105.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Nah. Just cut myself. Jeff smudges some blood remnants on his jeans.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you're off to Ohio State?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: No, Pittsburgh, actually. Can’t wait, taking art classes over the summer. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Ah, I’m going to Ohio State, I think.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Really. So is Mike. Whataya gonna major in?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Decowating! Thmmaaa!

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Thought Biology.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yep. A strained silence. Derf senses Jeff is lying.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yep. We could pop open a beer. I got a spleef left?...

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Oh, I couldn’t. I got dinner with my folks soon. Look, I’m sorry - you know, I think, wait, I do. I got some in my backseat. Been packing up... Derf reaches into the back seat and pulls out a sketch pa

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You got some of me?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Uh, huh. Here. The whole Fan Club. And this one’s you playing fife. Was supposed to be the cover of the Yearbook but it got shot down.  106.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Geez.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: And this early one. You can have ‘em. Jeff takes a moment to look at himself in the cartoons.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I don’t want these.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Just askin’... I dunno... you know, high school musta been hard for you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just had a lot on my mind. You sure you don’t wanna come in?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: No hard feelings?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I feel nothing. A strained pause.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: We were just having fun, you know?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I’m just like anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s gonna be great. We’re all heading on to exciting stuff. Mike’s blowing off the summer workin’ at the pool. Neil’s working for his dad, and Kent got an office job in Cleveland.  107.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’1l figure it out. Just like everybody else. How ‘bout one beer and all's forgiven?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Okay. They get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf steps toward the kitchen door. Moonlight spotlights Louisville Slugger left against the garage. Jeff is a cou of strides behind him. Jeff reaches forward and opens the door for Derf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark. Derf steps in. A strange heaviness jars him. H turns around. Jeff happens to be oddly close, right in hi face.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Oh. Hey, on second thought.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: I, uh, really should get a move on... Jeff looks at Derf in a weird way, confirming Derf’s instinct. Derf slides past Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf heads back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Sorry, my mom will kill me if I don’t get back for dinner. See ya on the flipside, Dahmer. Jeff picks up the bat, following Derf to the car. A few s behind as Derf swiftly shuts his door and reverses out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff heads back inside and lurks around the living room. lights. An eerie glow of splintered moonlight casts throu the windows. Those monstrous thoughts bubble up:  108.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Okay... alright... okay... alright...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf gets farewell hugs from his proud parents, Carol and Richard. He tosses his duffel bag in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We’re so proud of you, John.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Call us when you get to your dorm.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We love you.

dialogues.speaker: DERF
dialogues.text: Love you too, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derf slows down and looks over at Dahmer’s home. The ligh are still all off. No life in sight. Derf slowly rolls pa then continues up the hill and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty beer cans on the carpet. A pizza delivery box too. Seated on the sofa, a disheveled JEFFREY DAHMER stares blankly out the large wall of open windows. Summer air an the sounds of birds swoop in. Jeffrey checks the refrigerator. It’s practically empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeffrey gets in the AMC Pacer and tears out of the drivew 101 WMMS blares on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: DJ DENNY SANDERS
dialogues.text: And this next song is dedicated to everyone headin’ home from the Michael Stanley concert at Chippewa Lake. He’s one of Cleveland’s hometown favorites. You’re turned to Buzzard Radio 101 WMMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeffrey cruises along Cleve-Mass Road with a six-pack of on the passenger seat. He pounds one, then another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeffrey spots a SHIRTLESS HITCHHIKER, 19, dark complexion washboard stomach, with his thumb up - hoping for a ride. Jeffrey passes by, then impetuously decides to pull over. leans over and opens the car door. Via the rear view mirr Jeffrey watches the Shirtless Hitchhiker run to him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Hey, you just get out of the concert too?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRTLESS HITCHHIKER
dialogues.text: Yeah! Great show.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Where you headed?

dialogues.speaker: SHIRTLESS HITCHHIKER
dialogues.text: I got this far, headed back to Akron.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Wanna party some more? Jeff offers a beer.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRTLESS HITCHHIKER
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Get in. My name’s Jeffrey. Shirtless Hitchhiker gets in.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRTLESS HITCHHIKER
dialogues.text: Steven Hicks. Nice to meet you. EXT. CLEVE-MASS ROAD - BATH, OH —- DAY They drive off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: On June 18, 1978, Steven Hicks returned to Jeffrey Dahmer’s home. He was never seen again. FADE OUT.
